TALK.START.PARA: — The extracts which the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) quoted from the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) are indeed an accurate description of the economy, and he knows it. Indeed, he has said similar things inside and outside this Parliament concerning the external factors applying to this country 's economy at present. Also he and a number of union leaders have made observations which indicated that there has been an excessive growth in wages which has only aggravated the situation. I recall that the honourable member, when he was President of the Australian Labor Party and President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, acknowledged on a Monday Conference program- I recollect it being in about 1976-that there had been a massive wages explosion in 1973 and 1974. He was one of the first leaders of the Labor movement to acknowledge that that was so. It is interesting, therefore, to look at the table which he has incorporated in Hansard from this year's Budget Papers. The figures of real unit labour costs for 1975-76 are, indeed, the same on that index as they are in the second half of 1981-82. But what the honourable member omitted to say is that in 1972-73-you, Mr Speaker, were the Treasurer for the first part of that financial year-the real unit labour cost index was 101 as opposed to 108 in 1975-76.

SPEECH.PARA: What the honourable member for Wills, and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in his speech on the Budget, seem to regard as respectable is the wages explosion of 1973-74 which took the real unit labour cost figure to that height. In the intervening period the Government has worked very hard, as the table demonstrates, to bring that figure down. It is the resultant wages explosion to which the honourable member referred which has brought it back to that situation . The Leader of the opposition expressed some satisfaction with that situation in his speech on the Budget but the honourable member for Wills, quite skilfully I thought, steered away from expressing that satisfaction, which shows a degree of intellectual integrity. Most of the matters to which the honourable member referred were irrelevant to the real management of the economy. The Prices Justification Tribunal had reached a stage where it was justifying prices which the market could not bear and which would have aggravated inflation had the market been able to bear them. We have, in fact, strengthened the Trade Practices Commission and it has a prices surveillance role, albeit not what the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party would have. Let us look at what the ACTU and the ALP would do. Again, it is interesting that not a word has been said by the honourable member for Wills in this debate, or other debates, about what Labor would do were it in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—The honourable member said that is not true.
—Look at my Budget speech.

—I must confess that the honourable member for Wills said something in his speech on the Budget but he has not said anything in his speeches on matters of public importance. He has attacked the Government, glossing over the need for some constructive alternative to be put. I think I must say that in fairness to members of the public who are trying to make sense of this debate. On the face of it, the statements that the member for Wills made in his speech on the Budget and the ACTU-ALP prices and incomes so-called agreement in principle would appear to commit the ALP to supporting full indexation of wages for consumer price index movements. The honourable member has indicated in other statements that there is at this stage in our economy a need for some restraint and for partial indexation. I would like to hear a little more from him on that point. When it comes to attributing blame for the situation let us go to the authority itself, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. When the Full Bench of the Commission abandoned indexation on 27 June 1979 it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For reasons which will become clear, we do not propose to follow the usual course of detailing the claims and attitudes of the various parties as a background to our decision . . .

Instead, we will set out the circumstances which have taken us to the brink of announcing today the abandonment of indexation. Shortly put, the actions and attitudes of various participants in the system are incompatible with its effective operation . . . There are a number of interacting factors which have contributed to the present crisis.

The ACTU, some other peak councils and individual unions have authorised campaigns for increases which are clearly outside the guidelines. Past partial indexation decisions and the move to six monthly hearings are said to have contributed to an increase in industrial unrest.

Individual unions have accompanied claims for wage increases with costly and protracted strikes, bans or limitations aimed at softening up the employers in negotiation and the Commission in arbitration.
A number of other points were made by the Commission. A little further in its decision, the Full Bench of the Commission stated:
Many employers have insufficiently resisted claims outside indexation.
On page 4 of its judgment, the Full Bench of the Commission continued:

It will be apparent that no one group can be held responsible for the present crisis and any attempt to apportion blame would be fruitless. Experience has demonstrated that any action which may be regarded as a sign of weakened commitment will give encouragement to other actions inconsistent with the effective operation of the package.

The views of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission are a far cry from the oration and the so-called analysis which we have heard today from the honourable member for Wills. It is ironic that when the Opposition examines the present state of the economy it should regard the wages explosion which occurred in 1973 -74 and again in 1974-75 as being an appropriate starting point and an appropriate situation. An examination of figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals that in 1974-75 average weekly earnings increased by 25.4 per cent on top of an increase of 16.2 per cent in the previous financial year. Quite clearly, that outcome can be attributed to the economic policy of the government of the time and also to its industrial relations policy. Is that the situation which the Opposition would have us go back to as a starting point for an adequate relationship between wages and other indicators in the economy? The wages and conditions within the area of Commonwealth employment were used as a pace setter. We have done the reverse.

Let us recall what the strategy of this Government has been in this area. We urged the Remuneration Tribunal to bring in a recommendation to this Parliament which was considerably less than-ultimately, it was about half-the amount it might have fixed on ordinary salary fixing consideratons. Instead, it decided that a salary rise of 7 per cent was the appropriate figure for the people within its jurisdiction. Subsequently, a similar percentage was recommended by the Academic Salaries Tribunal and then the private sector responded with a similar approach to private sector salaries. In fact, the Government wrote to leaders of the private sector urging them to follow its example. So far, the responses that we have received indicate that the private sector is doing precisely that. By that action we have not sought to make scapegoats of the trade union movement or the workers of this country, as the honourable member for Wills said. We have said that the lid was kept on but the contents exploded and without attributing blame-the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been at great pains to take that approach-we now urge everyone to accept restraint as a sensible approach. It is one thing which we can influence in our domestic economy. So many of the factors that influence our economy are external and beyond our influence.

We have done more than simply ask the wage fixing tribunals to follow the Remuneration Tribunal's example. I am pleased to say that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last Friday decided to follow that example in respect of the Public Service case. But we have done more than that in this Budget. As I and other honourable members have pointed out many times, we have listened to what the ACTU said it needed by way of budgetary measures to improve the real disposable income of its members, the workers of Australia, to whom the honourable member for Wills has referred. We then set out to meet those requests . As has been said by several speakers, the standard fitter, who has been a yardstick so many times in the national wage cases advanced by the honourable member for Wills in his previous capacity, has now received what amounts to a increase in the order of $40. He would need to get from a tribunal an increase of about $40 to give him in real disposable terms what he will receive in this Budget through tax reductions, the lifting of the tax threshold and, of course, increases in the family allowance. We have attended to the things that we were asked to attend to and now we are entitled to expect that the trade union movement will show some restraint and will, in fact, take those things into account.

It is significant that when the ACTU finally studied the Budget and finally made a genuine response to the Budget it took into account the fact that those taxation requests had been met and that we had, in fact, gone a long way towards improving the real disposable income of its members. The ACTU made three main points. I remind the House of them. It said that the personal income tax measures illustrated the way in which a government can contribute to industrial relations stability. Is that what the Leader of the Opposition or the honourable member for Wills said? No, it is not. It is what an ACTU resolution said with respect to the Budget. The ACTU went on to say that these measures satisfy ACTU demands this year for tax indexation and an equitable redistribution of the income tax burden away from lower income earners and families. As such, they alleviate the need for unions to build income tax increases into claims for cost of living adjustments.

It is this Government which has taken massive strides in finding out what the ACTU wants and, in the Budget, meeting the ACTU request to help in the fight against inflation by asking that wages move as little as possible in the next 12 months in order to play a part in helping our economic recovery. The fact is that the real unit labour costs now are the same as they were in 1975-76. That is not only unacceptable to us as an outcome but also it is a measure of how easily in the wages explosion, to which the honourable member for Wills referred , the hard fought gains in the first few years of this Government have been squandered. We hope that people will follow the example of a number of ACTU leaders in some of the statements that they made prior to the Budget and also Mr Wran, the New South Wales Premier and President of the ALP, who has made similar statements and introduced similar legislation into the New South Wales Parliament adopting the approach taken by this Government in its submission to the Remuneration Tribunal, and the Remuneration Tribunal's response.

There is no way that anyone in this chamber should be taking any comfort from the massive increase in real wages that occurred between 1973 and 1975. That ought not to be a satisfactory bench-mark. The Government takes the view very strongly that when there is an identifiable area within our economy which we can influence-in this case wages and salaries-we should do our best to influence it. We are satisfied that this Budget goes as far as economic circumstances permit in meeting the living standard requirements of people. We believe that the taxation reductions and concessions and the welfare measures contained in this Budget must be taken into account by the ACTU and that the best possible wages outcome for us is to have the least possible increase in wages and salaries in the next 12 months. We call upon not only the trade union leaders and the tribunals but also the employers of this country to think very carefully about any kind of deals which they might be tempted to do with certain trade unions. Those deals can be only at the expense of jobs. There is no comfort to anyone in finding those who are in a job getting more while more people lose a job as a result of that. There is no substance to this matter of public importance. It is most important that the examples set by the Government be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate my wholehearted and unqualified support for the raising of the matter of public importance by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's impetus to uncontrolled wage movements and its attempt now to blame such movements for its own abject failure in the management of the Australian economy.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), who has just spoken, suggested that the Government is not looking for scapegoats in making the claim that the level of real wages is important to all of the economic deficiencies being experienced at present. That assertion simply is not correct. This Government has been looking for scapegoats for its own inadequacies and deficiencies in relation to economic matters since 1975 when it first came into government. Let us examine some of those people and groups within the community that have been blamed by this Government consecutively over that period for its inadequacies. The Government has blamed the education system in general and school teachers in particular. It has blamed the unemployed themselves. It has blamed the trade unions. It has blamed industrial disputes. It has blamed State government expenditure and State government borrowing. It has blamed changes in technology. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his state of the nation speech in March of this year, finally decided, after all those other interests had been blamed, that it was the community's expectations which were too high. If the community were prepared to bring down its expectations all would be well. The Treasurer (Mr Howard), not to be outdone, decided to blame pessimism within the media. In April this year on Channel 9's Today program the Treasurer referred to 'the danger of the nation being talked into a deeper recession'. What we had then was a whole range of things on to which this Government has attempted to sheet blame for its own inadequacies.

Instead of this scattergun approach this government has decided to home in on two particular causes: Firstly, overseas developments and secondly, the level of incomes, especially wages. The honourable member for Wills has admirably outlined the background to the second of those factors. It is becoming increasingly difficult for the Government to blame overseas developments because Australia's performance is worse than that in comparable countries in all of the critical economic indicators. Our unemployment is higher; our inflation is higher; our interest rates are higher; our investment is lower; and our economic growth is lower than all those countries with which we might compare Australia. Let us have a look at the other cause-sheeting the blame home to the level of real wages or real incomes. Let me dispose now of the simplistic nonsense being peddled by this Government that the level of earnings lies at the basis of our economic troubles. If the Government is correct in this assertion then when real incomes are falling unemployment will be falling, inflation will be falling and real gross domestic product will be growing. During the first period of this Government, from 1975-76 to 1979-80, the real value of average weekly earnings fell by 8.5 per cent. If this Government's assertions had been correct unemployment should have fallen, inflation should have fallen and real gross domestic product should have grown. What happened? During that period when the real value of average weekly earnings was declining unemployment grew, from 4.6 per cent in August 1975 to 5.9 per cent in August 1980. Inflation increased again in the latter part of that period, from 8.2 per cent in 1978-79 to 10.7 per cent in 1979-80. From 1975-76 to 1979-80 real economic growth averaged only 2.5 per cent. So the assertion of this Government is shown by evidence taken from that period to be without substance.

Let us have a look at what happened after that. In 1979-80 average weekly earnings rose by 12 per cent against a consumer price index increase of 10.7 per cent-that is, real incomes rose. According to this Government unemployment levels then should have increased, inflation should have increased and real GDP should have fallen as a result of that increase in the real value of average weekly earnings. Let us have a look at what actually happened. Consumer spending increased. Private fixed capital investment increased. Unemployment fell from 6. 2 per cent in August 1978 to 5.9 per cent in August 1980. The rate of inflation fell from 10.7 per cent in 1979-80 to 9.4 per cent in 1980-81. Non-farm sector GDP increased by 4 per cent in real terms in 1980-81 compared with the average that I referred to of 2.5 per cent over the previous four years.

I am not suggesting that all one has to do to improve economic performance is to take steps to increase the real value of incomes, it would be absurd for me to say that. It is equally absurd for this Government to persist with this simplistic nonsense about the level of economic performance in Australia being determined and directly influenced by the level of real wages. As the honourable member for Wills has indicated, the Government has attempted to make the trade union movement and the expectations of trade unionists in Australia about their material welfare the scapegoats for the Government's own inadequacy. I assure the House that neither the Opposition nor the Australian people will allow the Government to get away with that. A number of such statements have been made by the Treasurer in his Budget speeches. The most recent statement, of course, the one to which the honourable member for Wills referred, introduced the Budget this year. The Treasurer said:
These adverse international influences--
I ask honourable members to note the words 'international influences'-
were compounded, by a significant worsening on the domestic wages front.
I ask honourable members to note the words, 'domestic wages'. The Treasurer continued:
The need for maximum wage restraint has therefore been much in the Government's mind in framing this Budget.

At present there is one centre of responsibility, and one centre of responsibility alone, which has caused the present economic circumstances. It is this Government's incoherent and obsessive persistence with monetarist nonsense that has found expression in Budget after Budget. This Government and the nation know that the Budget for the year 1981-82 locked the country into minimal economic growth, and minimal economic growth occurred. The Budget for this year has locked the nation into zero growth, and zero growth will occur.

I gave figures on unemployment in my speech on the Budget which have not yet been refuted. I said that unemployment by June of next year will go through the roof. Do not let it be said that the Government is not creating employment. As a result of this year's Budget the Government is creating employment for about 270 ,000 people. I will qualify that statement by saying that everyone of these 270, 000 jobs will be created overseas. I will prove it.

The overseas deficit of this country is almost $2,000m and because of the domestic surplus Australian workers will be thrown out of jobs. The Government's payments overseas for goods and services will exceed its receipts from overseas by almost $2,000m. If the expenditure multiplier for the Government overseas deficit is two, this deficit will be converted to total overseas expenditure generation of $4,000m. If average incomes amongst our chief suppliers are $15, 000 a year then this Government's overseas deficit will generate 270,000 jobs for people in overseas countries. Let us not have any further nonsense from spokesmen from the Government side in connection with what lies at the base of our problems at present. It is the crazy, obsessive pursuit on the part of the Government in relation to economic measures that has been responsible for that situation. As I have said neither the Opposition nor the Australian people will allow the Government to wriggle from underneath that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I point out that when I was responding to the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) on his point about the breakdown of indexation I quoted from a judgment of June 1979 and, I think, described it as being the case in which indexation broke down. Of course, it was in 1981 that indexation broke down. My debating point was correct and valid, I just attributed the wrong description.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stripped of its rhetoric the speech of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) did not have a great deal in it.
—Not that you would understand.

—I understood it all perfectly and I intend to demonstrate that by reducing the speech to its rather simple elements. The honourable member for Wills would have us believe that this Government can no longer blame, as it would apparently, world factors for our indifferent economic performance at this time nor can it blame wage earners, presumably, for any adverse effect that this Government might allege they are having on our economic performance. As I understood him the honourable member then attempted to suggest that the unions' claims and presumably the claims of wage earners were as a result of two factors . One fact was the expectations that wage earners were led to believe were theirs as a result of a speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and numbers of other speeches by Government spokesmen. The second factor was the approach of the Government when it was elected on the last occasion to cutting costs and the consequential abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made those points in two minutes, but that was the substance of the speech of the honourable member for Wills. He came to the conclusion that of course wages are relevant to our present economic difficulties but that what is needed is a policy. But in the time available, which I thought could have been used very constructively, he failed to give us that policy. The honourable member had a number 2 speaker. If this were a schoolboy debate, which it is not, one obviously would have listened to the second speaker's speech in conjunction with that of the honourable member for Wills. The honourable member for Hunter ( Mr Robert Brown) picked up only one of the points of the honourable member for Wills. That point was in relation to world factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —But picked it up admirably.

—The honourable member would like to tell me that he picked the point up adequately. On this occasion the number 2 speaker, who had the opportunity to spell out what the Opposition had in mind to deal with our economic circumstances, failed dismally. I wanted to hear from either of these Opposition spokesmen an alternative approach. Most people understand that we are going through difficult economic times. Most people understand that overseas markets are dropping and rural products will lose their gloss-because of drought there will not be products available to sell-and other countries are able to market their products in our country more cheaply than we can make them ourselves, notwithstanding our significant tariff protection and other restrictions which are involved. Most people understand that it is very hard to have lower interest rates in Australia when interest rates are high abroad. Most people understand very clearly that Australia relies for a significant part of its income, its export earnings, on mined products and that those markets abroad are very important. We cannot expect to sell coal and iron to other countries if they are not manufacturing steel in increasing quantities. If there is an internationsl downturn, of course, that will have consequences in Australia. I do not need a set of statistics to be able to prove that. I do not need to quote that chapter and verse: It is obvious for all to see.

SPEECH.PARA: When we couple that with very significant wage increases in Australia we see further that the country is losing its competitive edge, its markets and its ability to be able to manufacture products for those areas in which we have been able to market successfully before this time. Real wage increases in the present economic circumstances are a very real difficulty. We know that and the Australian Labor Party knows it. The honourable member for Wills in his concluding remarks admitted that. We know this fact because of our own experience. In the years 1973-75 we had a very rapid increase in wages in this country. It had the consequential effect of causing very high levels of unemployment. As a result of that wage explosion, as it was called, we saw an increase in wages in the order of 25 per cent on top of the 16 per cent increase for the previous year.

The Australian Labor Party recognised that that had dreadful ramifications. I think it was a previous Labor Minister, the Honourable Clyde Cameron, who said that 'one man's pay rise is another man's job'. Of course, we know that one of the significant reasons for the wage explosion at that time was the pacesetter policy pursued by the Commonwealth Government in the public sector. Of course, after a short time it reined in on that. But it was too late; the damage had been done. Later the present Government came to office and, through its arguments before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, indexation operated very successfully.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sabotaged it.

—The fact is that indexation was sabotaged not by the Government but by elements of the trade union movement which consistently went outside indexation and argued for significant reductions in working hours and for increased and over-award payments. In many cases, they were able to bargain successfully for those claims outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Which commission could go on honourably fixing wage increases across the board when significant numbers of parties arguing before it were going outside it and working out a separate deal? It could not go on like that. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission recognised that and, for course, we saw the abandonment of indexation. It is unfortunate because I believe there ought to be a capacity for a body such as the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to distribute the benefits of productivity increases evenly throughout the community. But it cannot be done when there are in the community selfish groups which want to argue outside that system and which want to take a great deal more for themselves; it only has the very harmful effects that we have seen.

SPEECH.PARA: In the post-indexation period, this Government has endeavoured, particularly through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), who is at the table, to put into place discussions to bring about an agreed result and an improvement in industrial relations and to achieve a worthwhile advance through co-operation. The Minister gave a very admirable speech last Friday to the Employers' Federation of New South Wales at its industrial relations conference, which was headed 'The Industrial Malaise-What is the Cure?' The Minister opened the conference and dealt with the problems of labour costs which , as I have mentioned, are very significant. I believe the honourable member for Wills also has acknowledged this. The Minister spoke about the Government's wage policy and the way in which the Government was putting it in place. He gave further details of the tripartite discussions which he had initiated and emphasised their importance.

In that speech he quoted some statements made by people in the trade union movement who recognised the difficult economic circumstances we are in and their responsibility to operate co-operatively in this area. He spoke of the importance of wage restraint; he reiterated those points in his speech today. He spoke of the Government's approach to the Remuneration Tribunal and the acceptance by that Tribunal of the Government's arguments that there was a need for wage restraint generally, and of the pursuit before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the wider case in relation to the Commonwealth Public Service. Although the Minister did not mention it, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission accepted the Governments's case in that instance. He mentioned the Government's approach to a large number of major corporations and State governments and its argument before them of the need of wage restraint and of their acceptance of it. The Minister also mentioned-I think it needs to be said over and over again-the Government's positive response to the request from the Australian trade union movement for a number of Budget initiatives. The cuts in personal income tax from November 1982 arose directly out of the Government's discussions with the unions and were a very important part of the Government's co-operative approach.

—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed mining leases against the advice of conservationists and a State Government sponsored Public Enquiry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of the Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and
(b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the indiscriminate denial of the telephone rental concession to pensioners who share accommodation with others whose weekly income is greater than $104.15 is causing many needy pensioners unnecessary hardship.

The vast majority of pensioners who share accommodation do so out of necessity, i.e. to help in defraying household expenses or to provide a home for their children. They do not derive significant financial gain through sharing accommodation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will devise a Household Income Test which will reflect the true financial position of such pensioners and will direct Telecom Australia to extend the telephone rental concession to all pensioners not deriving significant financial gains through sharing accommodation with others.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the Government's failure to act to relieve the plight of many Australians who are being financially crippled by high mortgage repayments.
That we protest on behalf of all those seriously affected by the current crisis in rising mortgage repayments and those facing the near impossibility of obtaining housing loans.
That your Government's policies are forcing a downward trend in the percentage of Australians striving to achieve the ''Great Australian Dream'' of home ownership.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should resolve to demand immediate Government action to institute policies which recognise our grave problem and will preserve and maintain the 'Great Australian Dream' of home ownership rather than continue to destroy that dream.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the Undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require: (a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and (b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are members of the Hartwell in the State of Victoria Uniting Church in Australia showeth that:

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council and the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your Petitioners, therefore Humbly Pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the Petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resorts, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Burke respectfully showeth that:

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE BASE, DERBY, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following elements of the work known as the redevelopment of Brisbane International Airport, remainder of works of phase 1, which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament-
(1) main aircraft apron;
(2) buildings and facilities including control tower, administrative area, fire stations, maintenance depot, electricity, water supply and sewerage;
(3) general aviation runway and apron pavements, and a general aviation maintenance area, and
(4) access roads, carparks and landscaping.

These elements, which are estimated to cost $115.7m at January 1982 prices, comprise only a part of the work referred to the Committee. The full work referred to the Committee was estimated to cost $164.6m at January 1982 prices, as it also included a common user domestic passenger terminal complex and a hangar for Department of Aviation aircraft maintenance.

In reporting to Parliament the Committee has made a number of recommendations relating to both the timing and the scope of the work referred to it. In regard to timing the Committee has reported in conclusions 1 and 2 that it adheres to its earlier conclusion that the provision of new facilities by 1986 will be premature. The Committee has recommended that the work be reprogrammed so that completion is delayed until 1990, in such a way that the greater part of the expenditure is not committed until the 1986-87 to 1988-89 financial years. After consideration of the Committee's report the Government has decided not to defer the targeted opening date of the airport by four years. The circumstances have not changed sufficiently since the original hearing by the Committee in 1979 to warrant such a major delay in the project. However in view of the levels of Commonwealth expenditure on a considerable number of other aviation projects, particularly in Queensland, and also because of the need to resolve issues of terminal operation with the major airlines it is now likely that Brisbane Airport redevelopment works will be commissioned during 1987 rather than in 1986 .

In conclusions 3 and 6 the Committee has reported that the proposal for the domestic terminal should be further examined when the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) and his Department have concluded the re-examination of the preferable terminal type. It has also reported that it was not satisfied with the need for or the design of the proposed Department of Aviation hangar. The Committee has indicated it will further examine both the domestic terminal and the aviation hangar and make a further report. The Government does not object to such action and further evidence will be provided to the Committee as soon as possible. In conclusions 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 the Committee has indicated that it is satisfied with the design and siting of the various other elements of the work referred to it, including the proposal to relocate the Kingsford-Smith Memorial, and has recommended the carrying out of these elements, subject to its views on timing.

I have already advised the House that the Government does not accept delay until 1990. There are a number of other observations in the body of the report on which I believe the House would wish to have the Government's response. In paragraphs 28 to 31 the Committee has expressed the opinion that, based on all the evidence submitted to it and on its own considerations, it was not prepared to accept that a balanced examination had been made of the full range of possible solutions that could be adopted which would permit continued operation of the present domestic terminal complex until the 1990s. The Committee was also not prepared to accept the view put to it on the adequacy of the present terminal facility.

The Department of Aviation in its evidence to the Committee sought to identify the problems in the existing domestic terminal area which already exist and will worsen with time. Improvements and changes to the patterns of aircraft parking, road traffic and car parking have been made during the last few years which have fully utilised the available ground space. With the commitment to the Queensland Government for the Gateway Bridge northern approach roads this area is being further reduced. Further development of the existing airport facilities to make them suitable for use until 1990 would involve high capital and operating costs that would not be justified for the relatively short period of use involved. The Government considers that the facility is already at capacity and no acceptable alternatives exist to extend its life to 1990.

In paragraph 34 the Committee indicated that it remains critical of the failure to develop a national priority evaluation of airport development needs. I would like to advise the House that the aerodrome capital works program results from consideration of submissions received mainly from the aviation industry and the operational and planning areas within the Department of Aviation. However, from time to time the Government, on its own initiative, proposes items which it considers to be in the public interest. As a result the priority of airport development programs is continually under review.

The Committee was also concerned about and critical of the fact that the differing views on the selection of a common user type or a joint user type of terminal that have been put forward were not resolved before the proposal was referred to it. The proposal referred to the Committee was in accordance with Government policy and therefore it was appropriate that the Department of Aviation proceed with the referral even though the agreement of Ansett Airlines of Australia could not be obtained to the common user principle of operation by the time that the hearing was held. The Department of Aviation is actively pursuing this issue with the airlines.

The Committee expressed the view at paragraph 63 that there is an obligation on all parties to ensure that effective consultation takes place before a proposal is presented at a public hearing. The Committee further stated that, while many organisations were contacted on this proposal, questions were debated before the Committee which should have been resolved beforehand. The Government agrees with the need for effective consultation on proposals before presentation at a public hearing. Such consultations were carried out in this instance but did not always achieve agreement. The proposals put forward represented what appeared to be a satisfactory compromise. One of the purposes of the public hearing is to allow dissenting views to be canvassed in a public forum. What occurred in this case was an example of the canvassing of such dissenting views. I seek the agreement of the House for the elements of the work contained in the motion to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Asian Development Fund Bill authorises a further contribution by Australia to the Asian Development Bank for the purposes of the Asian Development Fund. The Bill replenishes the Fund for the third time. The amount that Australia will contribute to the Fund will not exceed $212,332,030. The Fund is a very important one. We played a leading role in the establishment of it in 1974. It was first replenished in 1976. It operates in the Asian-Pacific regions in a similar fashion to the World Bank's soft lending affiliate, and provides help to Third World, poorer countries. Some idea of the value of the work it does can be ascertained from the fact that the Bank has lent about $US10 billion for projects involving transport, communications, industry and electric power as well as agriculture, education, water supply and urban development. In recent years an increasing proportion has been devoted to agricultural development and to social development, for example in health, population and water supply projects.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter for concern that the United States has been unable to maintain its contribution to this Fund. Therefore, the target for the Fund has had to be reduced, and that is a very retrogressive operation. The Fund hoped to achieve a target of about $US4.1 billion but it has had to be reduced to $US3.2 billion. Australia, though, has had to increase its share from 5.14 per cent to 7.2 per cent. This represents no real increase in our contribution as the total target has been decreased but the replenishment is in line with Australia's share in the Bank's capital stock. It is worthy of note that when the Fund makes what it calls procurement decisions to implement projects, Australia's share of the contract disbursements has been much less than its proportional contribution, which, some have said, is due to the fact that Australia is less competitive. But I very much doubt that statement when we look at the type of projects the Bank engages in-irrigation and matters of that type. In my view Australia is a world leader. I have had discussions with representatives of the Bank in Manila. It was felt that we did not have enough consultancy expertise in Manila. I think that is a matter we certainly should be able to remedy quickly. It is rather sad to have to make this comment, but the head of the World Bank, Mr McNamara, stated:
For the first time in 50 years the US is saying that it cannot afford to continue increasing its aid program . . .

I do not think that statement is altogether valid. I am mindful of the fact that General Haig said that there was some need for long term and generous concessional aid to the very poorest countries. I think we would all agree with that, but we would hardly agree with the fact that it is important, according to the present Administration of the United States, that the Third World should rely mainly on private capital and market forces to overcome the problems of development.

What concerns the Opposition is the exploitation of cheap labour, often removing people from their villages and home environment, to work in very difficult conditions on the basis that they would be better off economically. All these people do is make a blouse or a pair of jeans and their pay is minimal . They do not even get the benefit of the product. In our own nation I think there is the rather short sighted attitude that we are helping the poor in these countries by putting them on a concrete floor. They work for 12 hours a day for as little as $1. That is deemed to be economic progress. I think it is important that we consider what this Bank is all about. Health, hygiene, education, transport, housing and matters such as that are much more important for the Third World. The countries which qualify for assistance do not have a large gross national product. It has to be under $US200 at 1976 levels. The people are virtually on a starvation diet. It is counterproductive to have people in a number of areas importing food when, with a bit of intelligence and aid, our farmers and experts could intruct them in what is called dry land farming, water conservation and, particularly, irrigation, together with rice cropping methods that we are able to develop here. It would be of much greater advantage to these people if they could produce their own food without having to work in a factory and not earn enough to live on.

Another serious matter concerns Vietnam and the attempts being made to isolate it. I know that Vietnam is a former enemy of the United States and Australia, but peace has come about. If we are to maintain it it is important to give aid that is of value to the people of Vietnam. We are talking about people, not administration. The Asian Development Bank has rejected applications from Vietnam because the United States has objected. Vietnam joined the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, and it clearly qualifies for assistance but it does not get it. No loan has been made to Vietnam since 1975. The directors have denied funds for new projects to Vietnam alone of all the Bank's 21 borrowers. Vietnam is certainly creditworthy because a report of the International Monetary Fund of October 1977 stated:
The long run economic prospects appear favourable. Vietnam is rich in natural resources, and has a disciplined and educated work force.

It is no good complaining, as we are prone to do, that Vietnam is taking aid from the Soviet Union. It has nowhere else to go. If the idea of the Development Fund is to foster economic growth and co-operation in the Asian region then Vietnam qualifies. Denying it funds is obviously trying to maintain the view that we can keep Vietnam poor and bring it to its knees. On the contrary; we are just driving it into the arms of the Soviet Union. One can see the problems that would arise if another super-power decided to establish a number of bases there. It certainly would not be of any advantage to China and it does nothing for peace and stability in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —All they have to do is get out of Cambodia.

—They will get out of Cambodia if China stops supporting Pol Pot . I am delighted that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) will not recognise Pol Pot. I have been in the camps in Kampuchea. One of the persons the people in the camps are the most frightened of is Pol Pot-this genocidal maniac who has destroyed three million people. I have spoken to Nguyen co Thach, the Vietnamese Foreign Minister. It might do us a world of good to invite him to Australia. He will tell us that Vietnam will get out of Kampuchea if Pol Pot is disarmed. But Vietnam will not leave itself in a position where it could have a surgical strike by China from the north and a simultaneous action by Pol Pot from the west. I spoke recently to an Italian Roman Catholic aid worker from Kampuchea who said that the people have never seen things so improved since Pol Pot has been pushed back. Unfortunately it has been suggested that Thailand is harbouring Pol Pot. If we have that sort of difficulty we are really looking for further danger. The Minister should not make interjections like that again unless he wants to be helpful. I have been to Vietnam. We had a paltry dairy project there. We cancelled that project as some sort of retribution. The Catholic Bishop of Hanoi is pleading for aid. He does not want aid for any armament purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude with this question: How counterproductive is it to see one of the Lebanese leaders deploring the fact that the Palestinians have been massacred by bombs and bullets all made in the United States of America? The Government should not get us into that issue. It should talk about how we can help people in the world. This Bill does something towards that. I wish to make it very clear that when a Labor government comes into office we will do two things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be off.

—The Minister for the Capital Territory will be off for sure. The point I am trying to make is that when a Labor government comes into office we will be establishing direct opportunities to give aid to the people of Vietnam. By the same process we will be trying to negotiate with the Chinese to guarantee that no more aid is given to Pol Pot and that he is disarmed. If we do that we will solve the problem which seems to be causing the Minister some concern. The Opposition supports the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Experience has clearly shown that one of the most effective ways of assisting the world's developing countries-we are now concerned with a number of the world's developing countries-towards growth and modernisation has been through the international development banks which have been established around the world. These banks are created not merely to lend money but also to provide other forms of assistance, advice and guidance to these countries. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I want to make some points during this debate concerning Australia's relationship with countries in Asia and the Pacific region. I believe that the remarks are related very directly to the general import of the legislation that we are now debating. Australians must now realise that we are not an outpost of Europe. In many respects we have been forgotten by Europe. Perhaps it is also fair to say that we have forgotten Europe. This is only natural because, in a physical sense, we are so far removed from Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important in this day and age for us to realise just where we are as a country. We must realise our identity and where we are situated in the world. Australia should recognise that it is close to both Asia and the Pacific nations. We must do all we can to develop the closest possible relationship with all of the nations in our region. If we develop closer links with our friends in Asia and the Pacific we must not only say the right things but also act in the right way. This means that we must make a real contribution to the poorer nations of the region but, at the same time, show an appreciation of the significance and the importance of these nations, no matter how small or how poor they may be. A close relationship can also benefit Australia. We may be able to learn a great deal from these nations in terms of their culture and their lifestyle. It is not a one-way thing. They may be able also to learn from us but we can also learn from them.

As evidenced by this Bill and the sum of money we are providing by way of the Bill, we can and should make a material contribution to these nations. In my view we should not seek immediate, tangible benefits in return for any assistance that we may give. Part of the reason why our standing is so high in Asia and the Pacific region is that we have given aid freely, without strings being attached; without giving with one hand and taking away with the other. I think some other nations have fallen down in this respect. Whenever they have given money they have expected something immediately in return. I honestly believe that our standing is very high in this region.

Genuine friendship, whether personal or international, should not be selfish or a matter of convenience. That is not the way in which we should approach relations in Asia and the Pacific region. Nevertheless, our own national interests cannot be ignored. If our taxpayers are willing-as I believe they are- to give large sums of money as assistance to these poorer nations it is only fair that our industries should have an opportunity to sell in the market places of these countries. Again, this is a two-way thing. Those countries should also, over time, have a chance to sell in Australia. But such moves should always be gradual; they should not be sudden. The moves should be sensible, bearing in mind that at this time Australia is not free of economic problems, especially unemployment.

Part of being close to Asia and the Pacific involves opening our doors to allow reasonable numbers of people from the region to settle permanently in this country. I am pleased to say that our immigration policies are no longer racially based. I think that is only right and proper. It is moral; it is also practical and sensible. For some years now consecutive Australian governments have seen the dangers of allowing Australia to appear to be a white outpost of Europe. I believe that if we had remained a white outpost of Europe it would have spelt disaster in the longer term. I am always sorry to hear the remarks made by people such as Mr Ruxton and others which may appear to be racially based; they certainly seem to be racially based. I think those kind of remarks and those people are on the wrong tram. I think those people have to grow up and realise the sort of country we are now and the sorts of people we now have here. I believe very strongly that our existing policies are sensible. I think the Government is doing a good job. I think the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) is also doing a very good job.

Some people say that we are part of Asia or part of the Pacific. I do not agree : Australia is Australia. It is as simple as that. We are different in many respects from the nations of Asia and also from the small Pacific nations. But as I have said, we must do all we can to develop closer ties with the countries in this general region. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs knows, I am concerned about our relationship with countries in the Association of South East Asian Nations. The five ASEAN nations-Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand-are among the participants in the Asian Development Fund about which we are now talking. I do not believe that our relationship with ASEAN is as close as it might be. Certainly I acknowledge that Australia has repeatedly stressed its strong support for ASEAN. As ASEAN has moved to adopt common foreign policy approaches it has become increasingly important for Australia to have a continuous process of frank consultation with these countries. The consultative structure established in 1978 enables important areas to be dealt with effectively at senior officer level. I think the ASEAN- Australian forum also plays a very important role. It meets annually, and that is helping to develop good relations between our country and the country members of ASEAN.

It should be acknowleged that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is making every effort to develop warm and friendly relations with his counterparts in Asia and particularly in the ASEAN countries, as did his predecessor. I congratulate them for their work. The officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs-the ambassadors, the high commissioners and others-are also making every effort to seek to cement closer ties in South East Asia. I make the point that they should and must do so. If one looks at all of the issues in which we are involved in relation to the foreign relations and foreign affairs of Australia, I believe it can be seen that none of the issues is of greater significance than our relations with South East Asia. These countries form an umbrella immediately to our north. They are heavily populated countries and they are gaining in strength in many respects-economically and in other ways.

Honourable members need only to look at the population of some of these countries. Indonesia has a population of 157,595,000 people; Malaysia 14,661,000 ; the Philippines 51,574,000; Singapore 2,472,000 people; and Thailand 49,823, 000. So there are many people living in these countries. As I have said, good relations with these countries should be our number one priority in social, economic and defence terms. But I am very concerned, as I have said to the Minister before, that we appear to be on the outside. Relations are said to be warm and friendly. I do not believe that they are as warm as they should be. These countries still see us as being quite different from them and having different interests and different ambitions. While this attitude continues our relationship will be polite but it will be only lukewarm. I see strategic dangers in the strengthening of ASEAN but with Australia excluded. At the moment that area is quite stable in a political or military sense and it is also strongly anti-communist. But what will happen if ASEAN, at some future time, falls into the wrong hands? What protection will there be for Australia? I think this is a very important issue. This is why we must ensure that we have the closest possible relations with these countries.

I feel also that there are dangers that we will miss out on the tremendous economic development that is now taking place in the ASEAN region. This is the area of great economic growth at the moment. Its economic growth is probably more than it is in any other area of the world. These nations are becoming quite powerful and quite wealthy-certainly when compared with former days-and their standards of living are rising at a rapid rate. If we can develop much closer ties we can participate in this economic development of South East Asia and gain significant benefits from it. As I have said, I do not underrate the efforts that have been made by the Department of Foreign Affairs and others. I know that there has been much contact in various ways There have been bilateral projects and a whole range of different kinds of contacts. However, I believe that more can and should be done to make our relationship with ASEAN genuinely warm and friendly.

The Asian Development Fund also applies to the Pacific region. Many countries gain benefit from it. The Pacific region is important to Australia and we are also important to it. We can play a leading role in the Pacific region, especially in helping those nations to develop democratic systems of government and strong economies. But I want to make an important point: I do not think we should seek to dominate this region in any sense. That would be the wrong move. We should not try to make this area our own sphere of influence. It is a matter of Australia being one among equals, on an equal basis with these other nations. Although we may have a stronger economy and a larger population we should see ourselves as equals and the other countries should see us as being equal with them.

Having travelled to a number of Pacific countries over recent years I am satisfied that Australia's standing in the Pacific area is very high at this time. Our Foreign Ministers-the present Minister for Foreign Affairs, our previous Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and others-have made a conscientious effort to develop excellent relations with Foreign Ministers representing the island nations. I know a number of honourable members have also made an effort. It is terribly important that when members of parliament go to these countries they can really improve contact and good relations between our Parliament and the parliaments of these various countries.

As well as providing substantial additional funds for the Asian Development Bank we are now providing greatly increased sums of money for the economic and social development of the Pacific islands. I know that the island nations certainly appreciate very much that increased assistance. I believe that they will put it to very good use. But we must not become isolated. I see this great danger that we might eventually become isolated. We have ASEAN, this great umbrella to the north, which seems to think that we are something different. We have a lot of contact with ASEAN countries. We have this large Pacific area containing very many small nations with small populations. These nations may see themselves as being very different from us. I think some people still see us as British. Some people still see us as part of Europe almost. We must develop these close ties so that we can join in, virtually as a family, with the nations to our north and the nations of the Pacific region. We must not become isolated; we cannot afford to become isolated.

We must concentrate our efforts on bodies and organisations which are directly relevant to our region. We are in all sorts of organisations and bodies around the world. But I believe that we have to concentrate our efforts on those international organisations and bodies such as the Asian Development Fund and the Asian Development Bank which are directly relevant to our region and to this environment. There needs to be an emphasis in our foreign affairs on Asia and on the Pacific. We need to spend less time in Europe, especially in London, and more time concentrating on Indonesia, Malaysia, Japan, the Philippines and all the other nations of Asia. I am just picking a few. We need to concentrate more on Fiji, Western Samoa-where I went and had a very enjoyable time not so long ago-the Cook Islands and the many of her important nations in the Pacific. This is essential to our economic development and to our long term security.

I want to put a couple of suggestions to the Government and to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I do not have very much time left. One matter I raise concerns student exchanges. I have put this matter to the Minister before. I wish to emphasise it again. A lot of our student exchanges are with North American and European countries; some are with Asian countries. There have been a lot of exchanges in the tertiary area. A lot of Asian students have come here to study at our tertiary institutions, universities and so on. I believe that younger students, especially secondary students, should be travelling to Asia. There should be more exchanges with Asia. Children from Asia should be coming to Australia. This would enable us to get to know one another in a closer, warmer way. I refer also to political visits. I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made this point and that the Minister supports it. Politicians should spend more time in Asia and the Pacific. Again, we tend to go to Europe and North America a little too often.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for Franklin agrees with that statement. He has been to those places. I know that he has been to a number of Asian countries and to some of the Pacific islands also. This matter is terribly important. Politicians should not just be spending a day or two in South East Asia; they should be spending a bit of time there. More time than that is required. I believe that our political leaders particularly should spend more time in such areas, not just a day or two. It is hard for busy people to spend a lot of time away, but they should endeavour to spend a week or two in these countries. If political leaders from Asia and the Pacific come here and spend a week or two, I think we will develop much closer relations and will understand each other at a personal level. If we can understand one another at a personal level we will begin to understand one another's politics and the problems that are facing the various countries. Honourable members should not underrate the value of personal contact. I believe that it is terribly important.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to hear that Mr Gordon Jackson is on a lecture tour, at the moment, of Asian countries. One of our senior businessmen is visiting these countries and explaining the business situation in Australia at present so that they can understand our problems. No doubt Mr Jackson will bring back some information which will be of value to the Government in developing good relations with each country.
