SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Hodgman) pointed out in his second reading speech, the purpose of this legislation is to extend the period of application of the $80 per tonne subsidy currently payable to certain users of liquefied petroleum gas. This subsidy was originally introduced in March 1980 for household and domestic consumers and later extended to include some industrial and commercial users. At that time, the arrangements were to operate for a period of only three years, expiring in March 1983, but, after reviewing the scheme, the Government has now decided to extend its operation for a further 12 months. This decision has the full support of the Opposition, as liquefied petroleum gas has become an important energy source in many parts of rural and provincial Australia. Any attempt to remove the subsidy abruptly without notification and without adequate phasing out provisions would not receive the support of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe the consumers who receive the subsidy should be significantly disadvantaged in terms of energy costs relative to consumers in cities. It was the disadvantaged position that these consumers were in that led to the introduction of the subsidy in the first place. During 1979 and 1980, traditional LPG users suffered from rapidly escalating prices brought about by the second oil shock of 1979. Under the Government's policy at the time, the policy of export parity pricing for LPG was established and its price trebled in only 12 months. The Government was forced to take remedial action-action, I might add, that became necessary only because of the inadequacy of Government policy at the time.

Initially, the subsidy arrangements were introduced to assist consumers. When this failed to provide adequate relief, the Government introduced a new pricing policy for domestically consumed LPG. Under this policy, the price was set at $ 205 per tonne for all but petrochemical consumption. Since then, the weakness of the international market for oil and LPG has brought about relative stability in the domestic price. For instance, the present wholesale price is only $220.09 per tonne, compared with $205 per tonne which was the price which prevailed in April 1980. Because of this price stability, some have argued that the rationale for the subsidy is no longer applicable and the arrangements should be terminated. Although the position of traditional consumers is not as disadvantageous as it was, it is I think, important to remember that these consumers still suffer an economic handicap with respect to energy costs relative to consumers in the major cities and some provincial centres. Even with the subsidy arrangements, LPG is still more expensive than electricity and particularly natural gas or methane by pipeline.

Areas connected to natural gas pipeline enjoy a major advantage over those which have to rely on bottled or reticulated liquefied petroleum gas. That is, of course, reticulated through municipal gas authorities in provincial areas. It is worthwhile comparing the price differential between these two fuels. Figures produced by the Australian Gas Association show that the price of natural gas for space heating in Sydney is 0.50c a megajoule; Melbourne, 0.28c; Albury, 0. 35c; and Wagga, 0.55c a megajoule. In comparison, LPG in Griffith is 1c a megajoule; in Grafton 1.2c; and in Mount Isa in Queensland 1.7c. This is after taking the $80 per tonne subsidy into account. So the price is significantly higher in those areas. Melbourne at 0.28c is the lowest for natural gas and in Mount Isa a cost of 1.7c is the lowest price for LPG. It is about five to six times the price for natural gas. It is easy to see from these figures that the price of LPG is roughly double that of natural gas in most places. Removal of the subsidy would disadvantage consumers in these areas much more so than it would if it had been taken away in respect of city supplies.

In current economic circumstances it is also worth considering the position of decentralised industries that are dependent on LPG. Many companies are already facing difficulties because of the depressed state of the economy. The additional burden of increased energy costs which would come from removal of the subsidy could result in the failure of some of these industries and small businesses. Given the regional significance of some of these industries, this could severely depress the economies of the towns involved. The Opposition would like to see reticulated natural gas available to all major provincial centres. We have already seen a commitment to extend natural gas laterals to the towns of Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow in New South Wales. We have made that commitment as a party. When I talk about reticulated natural gas, I am not talking about reticulated LPG, I am talking about reticulated methane or pipeline gas. In Victoria this comes from Bass Strait, in New South Wales from the Cooper Basin, in Queensland from the Surat Basin and in Western Australia from Dongara and soon from the North West Shelf. However, the size of many towns makes the supply of natural gas to them uneconomic. It is only fair that the people in these areas receive some assistance to narrow the gap between their costs and the costs which their city counterparts bear when it comes to the price of energy in this form.

The other fuel which is available to these consumers is electricity. The Government's intention at the time of the introduction of the subsidy on LPG was to give consumers adequate time to convert to available alternatives, especially electricity. However, the applicability of this strategy must now be brought into question, given the problems associated with electricity generating capacity in the eastern States. The additional demand which could come from too rapid a rate of conversion would place considerable strain on an already over- burdened position in respect of our east coast electricity grid. The Opposition would still prefer conversion out of LPG in traditional markets because of the potential it has as an automotive fuel, but recognises that the urgency of the situation has lessened with a diminishing of te world price which, of course, affects our local price. Electricity also is no longer the low cost readily available energy source it once was. The economies of adding generating capacity have changed and the time lags associated with building additional capacity are also substantial. Another reason why the need to convert has lessened is the changing demand and supply picture for Australian produced LPG. Australia currently produces about 2.1 million tonnes annually, most of which is exported. Production from the Cooper Basin will add another 250,000 tonnes per year by about 1984 and a further 640,000 tonnes will come from the North West Shelf several years later. Two years ago it was believed that demand growth would be such that all Australian production would be consumed domestically by late this decade. This is no longer the case. Demand growth has not been anywhere near the forecast figure. There has not been a great leap forward in the conversion of motor vehicles and the demand for petrochemical feedstocks has fallen due to the cancellation or deferral of some major petrochemical projects. We have a fairly substantial supply, well in excess of demand. As I indicated, most of it is sold to Japan and some to other places. We are using only about 20 per cent of our production domestically.

We do not think that the balancing of demand and supply is likely before the end of the decade. It will not take place until the 1990s, if then. This gives greater scope for continued or even expanded use of LPG in traditional markets without leading to excess demand. The need to discourage traditional usage has certainly been ameliorated. This is not to deny the need to continue to encourage increased usage in non-traditional markets, such as the automotive market. LPG is an already available economic substitute for petrol, at least for fleet owners, particularly those returning to a common bowser or supply source. Given our declining level of self-sufficiency in oil, encouraging substitution out of oil and into LPG must remain a major priority in LPG policy formulation. The other major use of LPG when it can substitute for petroleum products is as a feedstock for petrochemicals. It is a pity that demand in these two areas has fallen, particularly given the widening price gap we have experienced over the last couple of years.

There is one aspect of the automotive use of LPG which I think we should consider and that is the question of safety. A week or so ago I noticed that an LPG tank exploded in a car in Hobart. Luckily the driver escaped unhurt, but incidents like this do more to set back the rate of automotive conversion than do changes in government policy. People are legitimately afraid of the damage which can be caused to them by an explosion. I think it is imperative that government, suppliers of LPG and conversion equipment and the users of LPG develop adequate safety standards and act to improve the safety record of the industry. Although explosions such as this are rare, maximum use of this fuel will not occur until the record of the industry improves and potential users are confident of a high standard of safety. Not only must governments develop adequate standards but also they must be enforced. The discrepancies between States should be overcome and a standard code adopted for all. After all, a standard code has operated in Japan for many years. Any visitor to Tokyo or other major Japanese cities will notice that all the taxis and buses and some other vehicles, particularly those which return to a single depot, operate on LPG. In fact, most of the Tokyo taxicabs operate on Australian LPG. The Japanese have achieved quite a high level of safety by establishing a high quality uniform code. This is what we should do here. The importance of standardising and improving the safety performance cannot be overstressed if confidence in LPG as an automotive fuel is to be restored.

I return briefly to the question of the subsidy for traditional users. I again reiterate the Opposition's view that the arrangements should not be terminated at present, given current economic circumstances. We would also prefer, when the decision is made to terminate the arrangements, that the subsidy be phased out over time rather than removed in one measure. Consumers should be given time to adjust to the additional costs that will be imposed. This certainly would be the approach the Opposition would take. It is worth underlining the fact that LPG became a popular fuel and replaced coal gas in gas reticulation by municipal authorities in the 1960s and 1970s because it was the throw-away product from Bass Strait. It was the sawdust in the system. It was not until after the Iranian revolution in 1979 that the oil majors, particularly the Middle East producers, saw an opportunity to give LPG a price status which it never had before. It is a wonderful fuel. No one would deny that. When Iranian production fell away and there was panic buying of oil in the spot market, the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries jumped in, gave a new status to LPG and lifted its price.

In Australia we have always had the problem of encouraging Esso Australia Ltd and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in particular to sell into the Australian market. They have always found that it has been as lucrative selling to export, particularly given the fact that the export price has risen so markedly. We have encouraged people to move into the use of LPG-people in provincial centres around Australia have taken that decision and municipal gas authorities have moved away from coal gasification-only to find now that they are hooked up to what has become an expensive fuel. So I think the subsidy is appropriate. We certainly have a breathing space. While OPEC is running at half production we will see a substantial glut of oil in the world and, therefore, the sense of urgency about supplies is simply being obliterated. We have seen the real price of oil actually fall, as the price has remained static in the face of inflationary increases. All the other petroleum products, such as LPG, which are by-products of oil production have experienced the same trough in prices as a result of the falling demand from the Western world.

With the subsidy, people in country towns will be given some years of adjustment so that the real impact of fuel prices will not hurt them as severely as we might have thought. It gives us some time for adjustment but it also underlines the requirement to get the gas laterals built and to get as many provincial centres as possible hooked up to the main trunk gas pipelines. This country is literally rotten with gas. There is gas everywhere in Australia. We are a gas prone continent; we are not an oil prone continent. Our problem is with the eastern to south-eastern portion of the continent. The city of Adelaide is short of gas and backup supplies are needed for Sydney. If we can find about one trillion cubic feet of gas in the next three or four years, or even half a trillion cubic feet, in the Cooper Basin area South Australia will no longer have problems and there will be an improvement in New South Wales. In Western Australia there is gas everywhere. It has the problem of an over-supply of gas. Victoria is being adequately accommodated by Bass Strait. The sensible thing is to give Australians the benefit of this very important and clean-burning fuel by , where possible, linking them up to these pipeline grids. It is the policy of the Opposition to build, where possible, as many of these laterals as are economic to build and to continue with a subsidy scheme so that over time, given the flatness in prices of LPG at the moment consumers will have a fairly substantial period of adjustment from the relatively low prices for LPG to the ones which are now prevailing. In the event of the removal of the subsidy this would be done over a period, again to lessen any economic impact upon industrial and private consumers of LPG in rural and provincial centres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will cut in half my speech on the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill to give the honourable member for Calare ( Mr MacKenzie), the National Country Party member, half my time.
—Fellow apple growers stick together.

—Incidentally, LPG does not stand for low premium grannies that we might be sending up to Brisbane. I do not want to get involved in the apple debate before I start on liquefied petroleum gas. I am pleased to support this Bill. It amends the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Act of 1980 to extend the present arrangement under which a subsidy of $80 a tonne is paid on LPG used by certain consumers for a further 12 months until 28 March 1984. Provisions have been included in the Bill also to impose limitations on the amounts of subsidised gas available to industrial consumers after 1 October this year. The LPG subsidy was introduced for three years in March 1980 with the objective of providing sufficient time for household users to adjust to rapidly rising LPG prices. The extension of the subsidy is largely to help the many thousands of householders, small businessmen and other consumers who depend on LPG to cope through a period of uncertainty in world LPG prices which are expected to rise in the next year or two. On the other hand, the Government does not intend that the subsidy encourage new large industrial use of LPG. This policy was clearly stated in 1980 when the subsidy was available to industrial and commercial users in areas where natural gas was not readily available. Over the last two years the competitiveness of LPG as an industrial fuel has created a situation where large, industrial consumers with heavy reliance on fuel oil could be encouraged to convert to LPG. The Government does not wish to encourage such conversions for a number of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I make this opening statement to explain what the Bill is all about. I intend to mention specifically the use of LPG as a fuel. Firstly, the resultant large increase in subsidy payments cannot be justified. Secondly, and most importantly , LPG is a valuable transport fuel and petrochemical feed stock. I agree with the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) about the use of LPG. There was an accident last week in Hobart. This accident puts LPG behind a lot. We have read of the accident that occurred in Hobart. There was an ignition and, consequently, the driver of the taxi was burnt. We found, subsequently, that there was a leaking tank. The honourable member for Blaxland mentioned controls. It is important also that LPG be a viable alternative to petrol. Motor cars and other vehicles can and do run successfully on LPG. There are many claims that these vehicles are easier to start.

I know a little about LPG. It is good to talk about it. I came in today with a nice chap. I said to him: 'Is your vehicle on LPG or petrol?' He said: 'It is on petrol'. He said: 'I can't stand the smell of LPG all day'. Those sorts of statements are not well founded. The Japanese, who import most of our LPG, run their taxis and their other motor vehicles efficiently and economically on LPG. The Japanese standards are up to such a level that they do not have the worries and the rumours that occur within Australia because LPG is the alternative fuel. I ask honourable members to remember that the price of LPG is only 50 per cent of the price of premium fuel at the moment. There are many claims about LPG. It is claimed that vehicles are easier to start; that there are fewer oil changes; that there is longer engine life; that less mechanical attention is required to engines; that the pollutants in the air are greatly lowered; and it is one grade of fuel. Admittedly, LPG has disabilities. Of course, it is fair to mention those disabilities. There are limited filling stations. That is an important point. Datsun manufactured a vehicle to run specifically on LPG. It was a fizzer . Datsun did all the work on it. It did all the sophisticated modifications for changing the vehicle to run on LPG. One important thing that Datsun forgot to ask was: What would persons living in the country or in a town in Australia do if they ran out of LPG? They would have to have that car towed to the next filling station.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would have to improve their marketing.

—That is where Datsun made its big mistake. Its marketing was all astray. It should have had a dual system whereby with a swing of a switch vehicles could go over to petrol. That dual system would be operating all the time so that we would have a car that could run economically on LPG. If it ran out of LPG the car could be switched to petrol. That seems to be the sensible way of marketing a vehicle. If we can get options on engines, brakes, upholstery and gearboxes at the time of purchase would it not be sensible and reasonable for car manufacturers to offer that dual system so that one could switch the car to run on LPG?
—There would be no room left in the boot.

—There are boots made today that people hardly use. Cars that are used by one or two people are manufactured with large boots. Not every person in Australia has a large family so those boots are sometimes not used.
—Not like us.

—No, not like us. Of course, one can have that boot fitted with an LPG tank. That would not be inconvenient to anyone. Some incentive must be offered to the car builders and the buying public to make the change. For example, changes could be made to Commonwealth cars. We do a lot of preaching and talking about what to do. Would it not be an excellent idea to say that 50 per cent of all Commonwealth cars should have a dual system-should have LPG and petrol? That is the only sensible way to tackle these problems. It is useless just talking about it unless somebody takes the initiative and makes absolutely certain that action will occur in the long term or short term.
—The Minister for the Australian Capital Territory is here.

—The Minister is here. He is a very good Minister. I like the way he tackles the problems in the Australian Capital Territory. This is one problem that he should tackle. He should inquire about car fittings and alternatives to petrol. People in the Australian Capital Territory are always complaining about the price of petrol. Incidentally, that price is the same as the price in Hobart . People in the Australian Capital Territory seem to think that they are the only ones who suffer from the high price of petrol. The price in the Australian Capital Territory is roughly the same as it is in Hobart. That is something that should be considered in the Australian Capital Territory. The best roads in the world are in the Australian Capital Territory. I would like some of the people in Canberra to come to my electorate of Franklin in order to see some of the roads there, and then complain. I do not mean to get on to that tack.
—Of Denison, as well.

—In Denison, of course. People should come to realise that LPG could be a viable alternative to petrol. It is 50 per cent of the price of petrol. We then require manufacturers to tune into that thrust. I think that would be a successful way to selling LPG. The unfortunate thing about it is that 80 per cent of the LPG produced in Australia is exported because of storage facilities and other factors. I think we need to do more about LPG in the long term. Every mile driven while on LPG in Australia represents a saving in energy and in the purchase of petrol from overseas. It means savings in currency, employment of Australians and less dependence on foreign prices. I say to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that I am being blamed for the price of petrol in Hobart. People are saying that over the seven years that I have been a member of parliament I have done a heck of a lot of talking on the price of petrol yet the price seems to go up all the time. People like to blame somebody in this world. I am afraid that they are directing their criticism at me. I say quite sincerely that I am probably the only one who has talked consistently about the price of petrol. The oil companies are coming out of this nice and lily-white. They are the ones who should get the blame in Hobart, not me.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to the matter of LPG. I do not want to lose the thread. The honourable member for Calare wants to start talking in a minute. Many taxis in Australia run on LPG at the moment. As a matter of fact, the taxi drivers swear by it for economy and reliability. I believe that governments, manufacturers and distributors have a part to play in the conservation of the precious commodity, oil. On current retail fuel costs most taxi operators would expect fuel savings. It is difficult to estimate them. The price of LPG is roughly 50 per cent of the price of petrol. Therefore, over a period of years, people know that they can cut their costs down by half. That is a great saving. It is a saving not only to drivers but also in economising on oil. That is the important thing. If we are to save oil we will have to tell other people in the community that they need to use an alternative. I think that the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen), a kindly Minister, wants me to stop. I know I have had my 10 minutes. I want to give the honourable member for Calare a few minutes. As long as he does not get on to LPG as an alternative to apples I think we ought to give him those few minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) for providing a little time. I wish to mention a couple of points regarding the liquefied petroleum gas subsidy. The largest file that I have in my office, consisting of numerous letters, petitions and representations from existing gas users, local government councils and the like, concerns the pressure exerted to introduce a subsidy on LPG way back in, I think, 1980. I welcomed that subsidy because it provided some relief from the wildly fluctuating and increasing prices of LPG at that time. That subsidy is now to be extended for a further 12 months. Again I welcome that initiative because there is still the problem of many areas of non-metropolitan Australia which do not have access to cheap natural gas being reliant on LPG as a primary source of fuel. Many householders, small businesses and other consumers such as public institutions would have great difficulty, certainly in areas of my electorate where it is extremely cold, in providing adequate heating for facilities if it were not for the $80 a tonne subsidy.

SPEECH.PARA: While on the subject of my electorate, I note that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) mentioned the construction of laterals to provincial centres in various parts of Australia, including the proposed lateral to Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow. It is still my understanding that the Australian Pipeline Authority is ready, able and willing to construct those laterals if there is a request and conditions of contract are met. I imagine the difficulty now is that the economics of the project are becoming more doubtful. The Australian Gas Light Co., which will be the distributing authority, has undertaken considerable potential user investigations. There are considerable doubts as to whether it would be a viable project. The project is largely dependent on a small number of major gas users being the key to the economic viability of the project. At this stage it is still in the offing. If there is a request for that lateral pipeline to be constructed the Pipeline Authority will be able to do that.

As the honourable member for Franklin mentioned, LPG is indeed valuable as a feedstock for petrochemical uses and as a transport fuel. While we are to some extent luxuriating in a surplus of liquid fuels at the moment one only has to look at the situation in the Middle East to realise how vulnerable we are to a major disruption to supply in that area. From memory the Strait of Hormuz, through which 80 per cent to 85 per cent of the world's tradeable oil passes, through which there are, I think, 80 to 100 tanker movements a day, is only 5 kilometres wide. With the uncertain situation in Iran and Iraq and also perhaps the infiltration of fundamentalist Moslem groups into Saudi Arabia, we could not in any way be assured of regular and continuing access through those Straits. I believe we must persevere with the use of LPG as a transport and automotive fuel .

I also agree with the honourable member for Franklin that we should look at additional incentives-perhaps to convert to use of LPG. Perhaps we need to do more than simply exempt LPG sales from road taxes-perhaps more than ensure that such road taxes would not be imposed before April 1985. The day will surely come when we will be very glad to have the substantial reserves of LPG in this country to use as a major substitute for our liquid fuel supplies. In conclusion , I too welcome the Government's decision to extend the subsidy. I believe some people will be unhappy with the limitation of 1,000 tonnes per annum equivalent for industry. It is my understanding that the existing industries that may have been established on the basis of LPG being available, subsidised and cheap will continue. I welcome the legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'this House censures the Prime Minister for his inability to maintain ministerial responsibility in his Government, thereby causing widespread malpractice and corruption'.

I move the motion not solely because we have before us the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry or because that report, amongst other things, is a searing indictment of the Government and a grave revelation of the impropriety and incompetence of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon); rather because it is the latest in a long succession of reports which expose the incompetences of the Government and its failure to establish accountability and responsibility according to the proper functions of a Minister in the parliamentary system. I do not go as far as the extraordinary definitions which have been given by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) from time to time to illustrate what ministerial responsibility is.

It seems to me that very simply the principle is that if a Minister is to administer his department he should know about those important responsibilities which are discharged within it. The test should be: Firstly, did he know, and secondly, ought he to have known? It is quite clear in this case that the Minister not only ought to have known but also did know. He has been searingly condemned by the Royal Commission report. He stands not alone in this respect. It is to the disgrace of the Government that it seeks to perpetuate its functioning on the sorts of crude standards that we have seen in the past- standards which exemplify, by their persistent excusing, the most defective and undesirable levels of incompetences in the administration of the affairs of this country.

What we are discussing today and what has been raised in the course of the Prime Minister's statement on the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry is, I repeat, only one of a long and devastating set of incidents which have happened since the Fraser Government came to office. It has established political turpitude as the norm for the conduct of the affairs of the nation. It was today, by any measure, an extraordinary performance by the Prime Minister. There was at all times the anxious, agonised quality of desperation. Instead of attending in detail to the matters addressed by the Royal Commission's report the Prime Minister undertook two things. Through an aggressive assault against the Royal Commission and Mr Justice Woodward and a former colleague Mr Bert Kelly, he sought to establish by selective and confused quoting and prejudiced presentation and, when it suited him, downright dishonesty-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is not entitled to use that term. I ask him to withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, this is a censure motion.
—Despite the fact this is a censure motion it is an unparliamentary term.
—Mr Speaker, you have allowed it in the past.
—I have allowed it in the past. I think the standard of debate would be lifted if we did not use those words.
—I see, we have a new set of rules all of a sudden.
—Yes, that is correct. I ask the honourable gentleman to withdraw the word 'dishonesty'.

—I shall not delay. I think this extraordinary variability in the way in which you interpret the Standing Orders, Mr Speaker, is something we should discuss. But we can save that for later. The aim of the Government is to get the Minister for Primary Industry off the hook. Why does the Government want to get the Minister for Primary Industry off the hook? For one simple reason: If he goes, if his resignation is accepted, then the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) should go. The last thing the Government wants is to confess that the resignation which the Minister for Primary Industry tendered represented a proper course of conduct which should have been adopted by both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General. The proper course of conduct should have been to accept the resignation proffered by the Minister for Primary Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: What the former member of this House, Bert Kelly, and the Royal Commission have established is the Minister's culpable neglect. Having established that, the Prime Minister comes into this House with the result today that he finds both of them guilty. He condemns Kelly and he condemns the Royal Commission for having established serious deficiencies in the administration of the Minister for Primary Industry. A consequence of this, I mention in passing, is that the behaviour of the Prime Minister today destroys the tradition of independent service on royal commissions. Any person of intellectual independence and professional self-respect from the legal profession will not serve on a royal commission in the future. Only lap dogs will be available.

Let us look at the people who have been found guilty-all sorts of people: Business, meat inspectors, police, public servants, that royal commission and Bert Kelly. Some of them in some cases to a limited or greater extent have been found guilty with justification, but a long list of them was found guilty by the Prime Minister. But no Minister was found guilty. Never is a Minister of the Fraser Government established as being guilty of inappropriate or deficient conduct in the discharge of his duty. It does not matter whether thousands of millions of dollars have been ripped off the public purse by tax evasion. We still find the same Treasurer here. We still find the same people in charge of the Australian Taxation Office. It does not matter that the overwhelming avalanche of legal opinion is that existing law could have been applied to bring properly to account people evading their tax-a criminal offence. The Attorney- General is still there. The heads of his Department are still there. Presumably people are perpetually innocent in the Fraser ministry.

The Prime Minister's speech today was a canter through a minefield of dishonest quotes and malicious misrepresentation. In the final result, it was a desperate effort to stand plain English on its head and to make it mean things it could not possibly say. He works on the principle that a fool is born every other minute. From his conduct today, he believes that Australia is peopled by a population that was born every other minute. That is gratuitously offensive. It is an unnecessary insult to the intelligence of this nation. Let us put this into some sort of focus. Let us commence with what the Prime Minister discussed today. On page 1 of his statement he declared that the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry was 'a royal commission of high standing and repute'. From about page 2 almost to the end of what he had to say, which took more than an hour, however, he seemed to have forgotten that because he set about in a quite malicious and mendacious way to destroy the respect and the credibility of the Royal Commission.

Let me give the House some of the illustrations. On page 5 of the statement that he circulated subsequent to his speech he quoted paragraph 2.75 of the report of the Royal Commissioner, which in part states:

. . . on the basis of the evidence then available, I would have reported that malpractice in the industry was rare, and felt compelled to recommend that, in the light of that finding, many of the present security measures were unnecessary and that no fundamental change in administrative arrangements was required to prevent or detect malpractices.

He makes much of that particular point, inferring that there could not have been much behind the malpractices finally established by the Royal Commission. It is a shame that he did not quote the last sentence of that paragraph because, in demolishing the argument he misleadingly and wilfully sought to set up, it says:
Such a report would have been totally misleading.
So the Prime Minister engaged in a misleading exercise so far as the Parliament was concerned. On page 7 of his statement, again referring to the post-scandal period, he quoted paragraph 1.19:

Returning to the Department of Primary Industry itself, it is only fair to say that, under instructions from its Minister, it acted promptly and effectively when the meat substitution scandal erupted.

He then quoted paragraphs 1.21 which, from the way in which he quoted both those paragraphs, seemed to be an approving comment from the Royal Commission concerning the functioning of the Department of Primary Industry. In turn, the implication is clear: The administration under the Minister for Primary Industry could not have been all that defective. Why did he not quote the following sections from the report? I refer to paragraph 1.8 which provides:

Another major deficiency of the export meat arrangements before August 1981 was that the DPI and the Australian Federal Police paid too little attention to those malpractices which did come to their notice. Those which the Department handled were often dealt with in a weak and indecisive fashion. On most occasions when police were called in, their work was ineffective.
Why did he not quote paragrah 1.15? In part that paragraph states:
The Australian Federal Police must also bear a share of the blame for those missed opportunities.
The 'missed opportunities' refer to deficiencies in the inspection service and its poor performance. Why did he not quote paragraph 1.16? In part that paragraph reads:
Not enough cases were passed to the police for action, and those that were handed over were not conveyed with any sense of urgency, importance, or great interest in their outcome.
Why did he not quote paragraph 1.17? That paragraph states:

On the other hand it must be said that the Department had little to show for those occasions when matters were referred to police. There were no grounds for confidence that police inquiries would achieve worthwhile results.

So much for the argument that the Prime Minister was seeking to establish by implication. The implication was that, if we approach this in the way in which he was seeking to persuade us we should, we would see that there had been some minor peccadilloes which were excusable in all the circumstances because we must weigh up the performance of the bureaucracy under the Minister for Primary Industry which was not too bad. It was damnable. It was damnable on the Department of Primary Industry and it was damnable on the Australian Federal Police to the extent that they have been involved in these matters. On page 9 of his speech he quoted paragraph 1.61, which in part states:
Generally, such matters as were referred to Commonwealth Ministers were dealt with adequately and effectively.
I think we should go beyond that and look at the range of matters considered by this report. They are dealt with in paragraphs 1.62, 1.63 and 1.64. Paragraph 1. 62 states:

However, I do consider that the findings by the Honourable. C. R. Kelly and Mr W. Buettel about the state of the industry and the DPI inspection service, in their Report of their inquiry into meat inspection services in 1978-80, received insufficient attention from the Minister, the Hon. P. J. Nixon.
That is quite contrary to the impression the Prime Minister was seeking to convey. The next paragraph says in part:
Although they did not give specific details to the Minister, when making their report, they described conduct amounting to bribery of, and blackmail by, inspectors which in my view--
Says Mr Justice Woodward, and I put his credibility, his integrity and his capacity to weigh these things up fairly and objectively well ahead of those of the Prime Minister--
should have been the subject of a much more vigorous response from the Minister and his Department than in fact occurred.
The next paragraph states:

But I believe that the Minister, having heard from a responsible source that there had been cases of bribery and abuse of power in his Department, should have taken positive steps to investigate the matter. In my view he did not deal with this allegation in a manner that was adequate and effective.
He was inadequate, ineffective and totally incompetent. They are matters that I want to come back to. On page 9 of his statement, the Prime Minister refers to paragraph 8.89 which reads:
Insofar as allegations were reported by the Department to Mr Nixon, I do not consider any criticism can be levelled at his handling of them.

They are specific allegations. They are post the exposure of the meat substitution scandal. They do not relate to serious allegations of bribery and corruption which were extensively evident-I will produce the evidence a little later-within his administration. The conclusion of Mr Justice Woodward is that the man was gravely and culpably irresponsible.
The Prime Minister quotes paragraph 8.39 when he could have quoted other paragraphs from the same report. Paragraph 8.44 states:
Anyone who had assumed previously that, by and large, Commonwealth meat inspection was functioning well, ought to have been jolted out of complacency by what the Kelly Committee had to say.
This Minister did very little in response to it. Mr Justice Woodward continues:
It is pertinent to observe that what the Kelly Committee said on this subject was, in due course, fully substantiated at the hearings of this Royal Commission .
He goes on in paragraph 8.45 to say:

I have carefully considered the Minister's role in this matter, having due regard to the responsibility attributable to senior departmental officers, the heavy workload which Ministers accept and the potential unfairness of looking at one issue in isolation. In spite of these considerations, I am bound to record my view that the Minister did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively.
Again we have a searing condemnation. In paragraph 8.46, Mr Justice Woodward says:
He says that he can recall Mr Kelly saying that it was a pretty 'shonky' industry . . .
The Minister said he recalled that it was pretty shonky, but it was not shonky enough to cause him any concern. Paragraph 8.47 states:
The possibilities of such action should have been fully investigated. . . .
That is, the following up of Kelly's report. Paragraph 8.48 contains a particularly damaging finding by Mr Justice Woodward. It states:

. . . neither the Minister nor his senior advisors took any substantial steps to look into the questions which had been raised by the Kelly Committee. They seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the Committee-the question of a single inspection system-and hoped that any problems of corruption or abuse of power would right themselves in due course. In the event, of course, they did not.

Can there be any more telling censure of a Minister than that sort of quotation from an independent tribunal? In those circumstances, I will refrain from stating that the Prime Minister was wilfully dishonest when he came into this House and gave selective coloured and downright dishonest quotations and say that he embarked on a concocted version of what this Royal Commission was all about.

On page 9, he quotes paragraph 8.48 of the Royal Commission report. It is very important that we have readily available what is actually said in the report so that we can compare the two. If anyone wants to argue that this is not dishonest , I would like to hear his or her definition of what is dishonest, because it would be an extraordinarily liberal indulgence not to declare that. This is how the Prime Minister quotes paragraph 8.48:
They--
The Minister and his senior advisers:
seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the--
Kelly:
Committee.

What he is trying to do is to discount the significance of Kelly. He is trying to establish a case that Kelly is obsessive and preoccupied, that he has looked only at a very limited area, that he did not really know what he was about and finally that there was not much in it. We will come to that in a second.
The Prime Minister quotes Mr Justice Woodward as follows:
They seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the Kelly Committee.
Mr Justice Woodward did not say that. That is more than selective quoting; that is cutting up the report with scissors as it suits one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the paragraph ahead of it.
—I will read paragraph 8.48 for the Prime Minister. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Thus neither the Minister nor his senior advisers took any substantial steps to look into the questions which had been raised by the Kelly Committee.
Then we come to the part quoted by the Prime Minister:

They seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the Committee-the question of a single inspection system-and hoped that any problems of corruption or abuse of power would right themselves in due course.
Why did the Prime Minister not quote that part of the paragraph? The answer is fairly obvious. I ask why he did not quote this concluding sentence:
In the event, of course, they did not.

This report is devastating for the Government. I do not believe that the Minister can continue to function in this House with any claim to integrity or self respect before the Parliament let alone the nation.

On page 10, the Prime Minister reverts again to an attack upon the Royal Commission report, quoting in a precise fashion paragraphs 8.39 to 8.45 as stating firstly that the Minister did not act adequately and effectively and, secondly, that Kelly's complaints were not adequately followed up. In fact, those paragraphs say much more than that. I invite the attention of the House to the reports. Having already quoted the paragraphs in full, I do not intend to go over them but honourable members will note as they attend to them at their leisure that they are devastating analyses, conclusions and condemnations of the functioning of the Minister for Primary Industry. He is unfitted for the high office that he occupies.

The Government is trying to demolish Kelly. The pitch of what the Prime Minister is saying is simply this: 'Kelly did not tell the police about this corruption; therefore, you cannot take him seriously. Kelly did not do anything about it himself anyway; therefore, you will have to take him even less seriously'. I will tell the House precisely what Mr Justice Woodward said about these matters. Paragraph 8.40 states:
Clearly, one purpose of that visit--
That is, by Kelly:

so far as Mr Kelly was concerned, was to provide the Minister with information the Committee had gleaned about the DPI inspection service which was not strictly relevant to the report and would not be fully spelt out in it.

Mr Kelly's diary record goes on. The reference by Mr Justice Woodward is to matters which were not relevant to Kelly's report, matters not strictly his responsibility within the definition of his terms of reference. The Prime Minister tries to destroy Kelly's credibility by this quite cowardly attack upon the man's integrity.

The other aspect of what the Prime Minister is about, especially on pages 10 and 11 of his statement, is to try to diminish the significance of what Kelly had to say. It is suggested that, in Kelly's view, the offence was only minor. ' Minor skulduggery' is the term that the Prime Minister has been playing upon as being a quotation from Kelly. He is, I repeat, seeking to establish Kelly in the public mind, by his wilfully distorted and wilfully malicious and damaging misrepresentation of what Kelly is about, as an obsessive person who is narrowly fixated, who does not have much evidence and who cannot be taken seriously.
Let me quote from the report to indicate what Kelly was about in his diary notation. Kelly's diary reads:

I went to Melbourne for the day to present meat report to the Minister, Peter Nixon. It was worth it because it gave me the chance to tell him a few of the notes that we could not put in the report, such as the bribery and blackmail which is so prevalent in the meat inspection game. Poor Peter is now to see what can be done.

Poor old Peter is half blind. But by the record of Kelly's diary note the bribery and blackmail were not just, as I mentioned earlier, an insignificant peccadillo, a minor aberration, an indiscretion that was momentary and could be excused; it was prevalent. To establish that point further I will quote the source that the Prime Minister used this afternoon. What I am pointing out is that the Prime Minister, by his contrivance this afternoon, by this nasty concoction that he brought in, misrepresented what the Royal Commissioner was about and what Kelly was genuinely concerned about. Those of us here who served with Kelly-to the extent that we may have had some differences with him about his approach to economic policy-always respected the man's inegrity and consistency. In one hour this afternoon the Prime Minister tried to destroy more than two decades of that man's work to establish that respect. The point is that the Prime Minister was once one of his friends, which shows what friendship does for one in the Liberal Party. By this selective quoting and misrepresentation the Prime Minister has embarked on an exercise designed to damage the Royal Commission and to try to destroy Kelly with one purpose in mind-that is, to preserve a simple-minded National Country Party Minister who just does not understand what his responsibilities are.

I said a few seconds ago that I would quote the Prime Minister back at him to demolish his argument in relation to the assertion that what Kelly is about is very narrowly based and shallow, that there is not much there. What he is really saying is: 'Look, this is a rather insignificant thing, a minor skulduggery', or whatever the word was. On that basis he is trying to write off the matter, forgetting that there is some literacy over here even if there is none in the National Country Party. We are capable of reading the Royal Commission's report and finding the embarrassing sentences that he left out because they condemn the Minister for Primary Industry. Here he is trying to establish a case, but there is not much in it. Poor old Bert is a nice, entertaining old eccentric but one cannot take him seriously! Let me give the quote that the Prime Minister used from Kelly's report. Page 17 of the circulated copy of the Prime Minister's speech states:
. . . AMIS legislation should include heavy punishments for administrators, VOs, meat inspectors and management et cetera who try to extract improper advantages out of the system in this manner.
Bear this in mind. The Kelly report states:
That this kind of practice has been too common in the past we know too well. It must be stopped in the future.

There you are-blackmail and bribery within the meat inspection system. It had been too common in the past. We knew that well. It had to be stopped in the future. The Prime Minister writes it off as a minor indiscretion that might have cropped up here and there. By his own efforts and by his own words he has demolished himself. Kelly may not have been specific in the terms in which the Prime Minister has defined that nature. Maybe he did not report the matter to the police. Perhaps he can be presented as single-minded on this matter. Perhaps the Prime Minister feels that, if he can establish these matters and fabricate an assertion that Kelly's allegations were minor, he can get away with it. Perhaps those things could be mobilised if-but it is a very big 'if'-there were not available the Royal Commission report, which demolishes all that falsification and, with it, the Prime Minister. There are a couple of devastating quotes in this report that deserve to be mentioned. They are respectively paragraphs 1.55 and 1.56. Woodward states:
I am asked to say whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective, or on the other hand, whether any illegality or corruption occurred.
Paragraph 1.64 states:

But I believe that the Minister, having heard from a responsible source that there had been cases of bribery and abuse of power in his Department, should have taken positive steps to investigate the matter. In my view he did not deal with this allegation in a manner that was adequate and effective.

That is a telling statement because he declared that he was asked to establish whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective; if not, on the other hand, whether any illegality or corruption occurred. He stated that the operation was not adequate or effective. Therefore he is saying, by an extension of that definition of his obligations, that the Minister presided over illegality and corruption, and he presided over it knowingly and tolerated it through his own incompetence. That is the gravamen of what the Royal Commission report is about.

It is no novelty for the Minister for Primary Industry to find himself in the midst of this sort of scandal. Let us look at his record. There is the Murray- Goulburn butter levy dispute in which the Murray-Goulburn Co-op Co. Ltd conspired to defraud the Government of butter levy properly paid to the Australian community for the benefit of the industry. The Minister presided over that and wrote off any action against that organisation. The Australian Dairy Corporation breached the guidelines in relation to the use of government guaranteed Reserve Bank funds. Nothing happened in respect of that matter. Again , the National Country Party-the Minister-interceded. In the case of the disposal of the Indo-Milk Corporation the Australian taxpayers lost $5.5m on the sale by the direction of the Minister. What sort of record of competence is that ? There is the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal, which has still to be concluded in this Parliament. Let us look at the outstanding points. The police report is yet to be tabled. The sum of $3m in a Singapore account of the ADC has disappeared down some sink of iniquity. The ADC breached the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum pricing arrangements in 1976 and 1977. What did his predecessor know about that? There were possible breaches of the law in the Philippines and Singapore. Has there been any collaboration with the Government authorities there? Departmental records of possible GATT breaches regarding milk sales to Mexico are missing. Records are not clear about possible GATT breaches in respect of milk sales to Thailand. Is it not handy to have records that disappear or are incomprehensive when one is in trouble?

After nearly a year the Department of Primary Industry has not yet produced a report on guidelines for the operation of statutory marketing authorities. I think it ought to be put on record because he is in the House, although the level of consciousness at this point has yet to be established, that the little Caesar of the Australian Federal Police, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), is singed by all of this. He is singed by the poor performance of the Australian Federal Police and by the identification of clear corruption infecting the ranks of that police force which he administers.

Mr Speaker, this matter does not begin or end here. It did not just happen in relation to this issue. There is a long history of this sort of matter concerning the Fraser Government. I shall not go over all of the examples, but the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs investigated the Narcotics Bureau, an extraordinarily important law enforcement agency in this country. The report of that Royal Commission searingly tore apart th Narcotics Bureau and its administration; it was totally corrupt. The Government sat on that report for several months. The Minister responsible is still a Minister of the Crown. In the period when the Government sat on the report, when it was quite evident that the Narcotics Bureau was not an authority for which it was desirable to enlarge its powers of intervention through telephonic means of interception, he took legislation through this Parliament that did exactly that.

We have currently before the Parliament the depressing diversion of a multi- million dollar health fraud by the medical profession presided over by the Government. I need scarcely refer to the tax scandal which has been blighting and distracting this nation for the last several weeks. It boils down to this: All the responsible Ministers are still in the Parliament. They are, by the Fraser Government's standards, still 'respectable' Ministers of the Crown. What is ministerial responsibility under the Fraser Government? I find it hard to fathom exactly what it is. Many declarations are made but no practices are followed persistently. Principles, it seems, are buckled quite simply. Perhaps we can get an insight into the matter from the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) in his, appropriately, gutterside interview outside Parliament House this morning. He was asked:
Are National Party Ministers getting preferential treatment? Senator Withers was criticised by a Royal Commission and he went. Mr Nixon is criticised and he stays.
The Deputy Prime Minister replied:
Well, you know I think there is some justification in an argument being made around the point.
Honourable members should listen to this:
I think there is some slight difference in that Mr Nixon immediately allowed his position to be in the hands of the Prime Minister for a thorough investigation.
He goes on:
What I recollect of Senator Withers there was some contesting of the situation.
Then he adds:
But, I suppose we can all learn from a bit of hindsight.

Of course the Minister for Primary Industry would say that he was putting his ministerial welfare in the hands of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister would not dare to dismiss him no matter how outrageous-as it is incontestably outrageous-his behaviour because he knows that too many other Ministers would have to go. But what is the principle? If a Minister goes along and confesses all and says, 'I confess. Please give me absolution and I will be better after it is all over', he is all right. If he fights back he is in trouble. That is when he goes. But the principle does not stand up because the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) did not seek to fight back. They sought to behave properly and they went out on their ears. What is the principle in relation to independent royal commissions of inquiry that conclusively condemn the performance of a Minister, establishing either his culpable neglect or his culpable impropriety-both of which apply to the Minister for Primary Industry. On the occasion of the less than celebrated dismissal of Senator Withers from the Ministry the Prime Minister, in a Press statement of 8 August 1978, said of the Royal Commission report of Mr Justice McGregor:
We were of the view that Mr Justice McGregor's report had to be accepted and accepting it had inevitable consequences in respect of the finding of impropriety.

That is the principle. If the Government sets up an independent judicial inquiry then, very properly, if impropriety is established-as it was then and as it is now-the Government has no choice in the matter. There must be a dismissal of the person who is identified as being guilty. So Withers from the Liberal Party goes but Nixon from the National Country Party hangs on. What was the position of the Minister for Primary Industry anyway when his colleague and friend from the Cabinet room, Senator Withers, went? I quote from page 124 of a document appropriately entitled War Without Blood, Malcolm Fraser in Power by Russell Schneider. It states:
Peter Nixon also wandered in--
The way in which this Government runs this country must be a great operation-
But made it clear he had no intention of supporting Withers. In his view Withers should have had no contact with Pearson on the name change whatever.

I will not argue with that. But on that basis the Minister for Primary Industry is even more culpable because his offences are even more grave. If he does not accept our description of the level of gravity he should have listened to what the Prime Minister said this morning outside the House and again this afternoon when he declared that these offences in their nature were even more serious than the tax evasion offences, and he regarded them as particularly serious. Where does the Prime Minister stand in all this? What is the principle? In 1975 we had this declaration of ministerial responsibility:
We will re-establish a properly functioning and responsible Cabinet government.

The Prime Minister was going to rewrite all the books on Cabinet government for the political science department. It is a bit like the Stalinist era when history was re-written month by month and photographs were turned to the wall. The Prime Minister in his electorate broadcast of 24 November 1974 said:

If there are rules and principles for action they must apply in all cases. Governments above all must apply rules equally to all sections of the community. If they make one rule for one group and another for another group government becomes arbitrary, unfair, and unreasonable.
But of course the National Country Party is more equal than other people when the calculus is done. In March 1978 electoral broadcast the Prime Minister said:
One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore--
How he uses words quaintly and eloquently-
The integrity and honesty of government.
What a shame it escaped everyone else's observations. But I am sure he will keep trying. He then goes on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with it.
—I intend to. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no government can hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people.

I will not give honourable members any more. It is too close to the suspension of the sitting for dinner. In 1972 the Prime Minister established the principle by which he has been inspired ever since but which he has totally ignored. He said:

It is certainly true that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments. They ought to be aware of all the major matters and therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them. But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his Department and offer to resign.

That is not novel. We have quoted it many times. Here it is, six pages of grandiloquence, the great principles. What is it worth? I will show honourable members what it is worth. I will show honourable members where it deserves to be filed. It deserves to go into the trash bucket of Parliament House with all the declarations of principles and integrity by the Prime Minister. Let us look at the Liberal Party patrimony, the ministerial records that it can live on and the sort of heritage for the future. We have attempted bribery, dubious property deals, electoral impropriety, multi millions of dollars disappearing down some sink of inequity in South East Asia, a rotten meat scandal and so it goes on. As I said, these are not minor failures but very serious things. Let us look at the Camelot court-the brightest and the best that is offered to Australia. Fraser's Camelot court is comprised of an Attorney-General who does not know his law; a Treasurer who will not enforce the law; two ex-Ministers caught running a small scale smuggling operation; a former Minister for Primary Industry whose only claim to fame in this Parliament is that of a handwriting expert; the present Minister for Primary Industry who luxuriates in the reputation of being the bovver boy of the national parliament and who is incapable of thinking his way through his ministerial responsibilities; a former Customs Minister who conducted a narcotics bureau as crooked as its quarry; and a series of Health Ministers from this conservative Government dedicated to preserving the sanctity of the doctor-cash register-relationship. Honourable members should have a look at the Prime Minister's face. It looks like he has been weaned on a pickle. Also there is the Taxation Office that clobbers the poor invalid pensioner in a wheelchair over the equivalent of morning tea money while Horgan's heroes ride into the West scot-free with their booty of millions of dollars. All the open, empty spaces in this country are not in the outback. A lot of them are between the ears of Ministers of the Fraser Government.

All that this Government has established in its seven years of office is a record of disgraceful turpitude. It has established the public sector under its administration as a huge, open, smelly sewer. It has resorted to scapegoatism, trying to establish the Public Service as the fall guy, the sacrificial offering in all of this. It is nonsense and it will delude no one. Public Service standards certainly are a cause of concern in a number of areas but they have deteriorated because of the way in which the Government administers its responsibilities. What this House is considering is an extraordinary litany of culpable negligence, gross incompetence and unbelievable slothfulness in ministerial administration by the Fraser Government. It just did not happen this month, last month or even this year. It has been going on unrelieved for seven dreadful years. It is just that, as time goes by, the incidents happen more frequently and on more numerous occasions with far worse implications. The Prime Minister pouts and postures about responsibility, integrity, ethics and decent values-all of the worthwhile things essential to a well conducted society. In practice he shatters them like a political hoodlum smashing plate glass windows.

We are not talking about trivial issues or unfortunate and excusable digressions from high standards. We are talking about a persistent pattern of behaviour which has about it the stench of a sewer. Australians are a decent upright citizenry. We may at times be rather direct and perhaps even clumsy in the directness of our expressions. For that we can justifiably excuse ourselves as members of a young and vigorous country that is still developing in so many important ways. But there is one thing we have always been proud of-that there is a fundamental decency and honesty about Australians and a deeply ingrained sense of fair play. The standards of the Fraser Government are in direct conflict with those fundamental standards of decency that go to make up the Australian character. Australians are sick and tired of the rottenness, of the smelly taints, of the tolerance of malpractice and corruption that the Fraser Government has presided over and of the bevy of incompetent Ministers the nation has had inflicted on it.

I say one thing to the Fraser Government: Take your filthy feet off the neck of the Australian nation and scourge your incompetent and failed Ministers from office, as propriety would demand. If the Government is not prepared to do that it will be scourged from office by decent, upright Australian citizens at the first opportunity given them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. The issue in this debate, which will continue for a little longer after the suspension of the sitting for dinner, is ministerial responsibility in a government. The incredible record of this Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is that in the period in which he has been Prime Minister 22 Ministers have either resigned or been sacked. We could add at least another six Ministers to that total if we could only get justice done. The point highlighted by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) is that it is not only a matter of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) being found guilty by the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. The issue now is: Why is the Prime Minister not prepared to accept the finding?

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that the Minister for Primary Industry appears to be in a select group of about three Ministers-whom we could regard as the untouchables in the Government-who will be preserved from being either asked to resign or sacked? Other Ministers who are now on the back bench, were thrown out because the matter involved was deemed to be of some significance to what is called responsible government. Senator Withers said: 'It is the little things in life that bring you down'. All we can say about the Minister for Primary Industry is that the matter must be a bit bigger than a little thing. It is, from looking at this report. What an extraordinary defence it is for the Prime Minister to suggest that because the Royal Commissioner left out some words-'when the new page'-is turned, one has to exempt the Minister from the accusations made.

Let us make this very clear. We all knew Bert Kelly; he is honest. He did not know much about industry but he is honest. From his position he made a report to the Minister in February 1980 saying: 'Poor Peter, it is left to you'. What was left to poor Peter? It was blackmail, criminal activity and corruption. That was what poor Peter inherited in 1980. The indictment is about the new page. When was this new page going to be turned? The only time the new page could have been turned was when the Government brought in some legislation that might have covered some of the ineptitudes of the Department of Primary industry. But no legislation was brought in until the following year-in October 1981. What caused that legislation to be brought in? It had nothing to do with a new page. It had nothing to do with anything the Minister had done.

This is a significant point to which the Prime Minister ought to address his mind: On 27 July 1981 a food inspector in San Diego, California, became suspicious of three frozen blocks of Australian meat. They looked darker and stringier than beef. Samples of the meat were sent to a laboratory for testing. The tests indicated that the meat was horse meat. That came to light only in July 1981. That was well after Bert Kelly had told the Minister. What did Bert Kelly tell the Minister? Honourable members should look at this report. He said that it could be said that the system was potentially explosive. It exploded in July 1981. Only after that was any legislation brought in. So the Prime Minister should not come into this House and say that, of course, he is going to turn a new page. No new page was turned until the crook meat came up in San Diego. It is as simple as that. Then all hell broke loose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, prior to the suspension of the sitting I was supporting the case for the Opposition which has censured the Prime Minister for his failure to guarantee ministerial responsibility thereby bringing about widespread malpractice and corruption. There is no better evidence of that than the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry which has been tabled today. I was making the point that, despite the best intentions of the Minister for Primary Industry and despite the fact that he was alerted by what is known as the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems, the report of which had a potentially explosive area relating to the meat inspection, the only time the issue became known to the Australian people was when a food inspector in California was able to identify meat that had been sold as good quality beef but which was, in fact, horse meat. In that simple expression we see that all the explanations made by the Prime Minister or the Minister or predecessors fall to the ground; there is something wrong with ministerial control.

SPEECH.PARA: Ministerial control does not apply in the terms of the Durack test: The Minister has to be found to be guilty of a personal failure himself. It is a much higher control. The Minister is responsible for the Department. He is bound by the mistakes of that Department. He is supposed to give instructions and guidelines to guarantee that when Kelly was able to alert him in February 1980 that there was something dramatically wrong with the Department something would be done about it. It is not, as the Prime Minister says, that there was to be a waiting for the turning over of a new leaf. I make the point that the first person to find out about the substitution was a food inspector in San Diego. Does that not make the Government look ridiculous?

Let us have a look at the sort of publicity we got in the Washington Post which carried the headlines: 'Let them eat Roo'; and 'How exports to the United States of kangaroo as beef has led to Australia's Slaughtergate'. Then we come to the question of the Washington Post using something that possibly no one wants to say should be a fair summation of the situation, but I think it is. 'The resulting publicity and scandals have done Australia immeasurable harm', reported a critic. We now 'have the reputation of some third rate banana republic run by a bunch of hucksters out to con everybody we can'. What has that done for Australia? These are the issues that the Prime Minister knows have been brought home. I want to make the point that not just the Minister for Primary Industry is involved. I have in front of me a letter written by his predecessor, Mr Sinclair, when he was Minister for Primary Industry, to a Mr Alexander. It is dated 21 November 1977. It states:
Dear Mr Alexander,

The Prime Minister has passed your letter of 21 October 1977, concerning allegations of export of offal from an unregistered establishment and its possible contamination with salmonella organisms, for direct reply on his behalf .

That is a complaint to the Prime Minister. Mr Alexander lives in Richmond, Victoria. Apparently he is a member of a council and was apparently inspecting a meatworks there. He was able to see this position. He gives evidence by letter to the Prime Minister. The letter continues:

The Bureau of Animal Health, which is responsible for the export inspection of meat and meat products, is aware of your correspondence with Colonel McArthur of the Australian Meat Board on this matter and has passed this information on to the Commonwealth Police. I am grateful for your offer to make yourself available during any investigations and the Commonwealth Police will be advised accordingly.

Finally I would like to thank you for your interest and assure you that my Department, with the Commonwealth Police, will take appropriate action to substantiate or otherwise, the allegations you have made.
I do not know whether anything more has transpired. I doubt that it has. This man is bringing the matter to somebody's attention. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
