TALK.START.PARA: —Let us now turn to the findings of the Royal Commission. Paragraph 1.64 on page 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: But I believe that the Minister, having heard from a responsible source that there had been cases of bribery and abuse of power in his Department, should have taken positive steps to investigate the matter.

That is the finding. If honourable members have a look at the other paragraphs they will see all sorts of extraordinary findings. Another finding states that the police officers assigned to investigate most of these inquiries seem to have pursued them with little sign of keenness or ability. That is an indictment of the police force. The Commissioner says that one reason for this was that they were getting free meat.

The Commissioner has reference to the files of the Department. When one looks at the report it becomes clear that many of the files of the Bureau of Animal Health, including some of particular interest, were in a very poor state; folios were missing. We have the classic phrase: 'The apparent deficiencies can be explained.' The report states that it is clear from the evidence of officers who worked on the files over the weekend of 5 or 6 September that they were in a bad state before the alleged shredding occurred. What are we about? Here is a department, as Kelly said, in a very shonky condition. There are files all over the place. When the police are sent out all they seem to collect is fresh meat- no other evidence. We have the position now where the Minister has been found wanting in his ministerial responsibilities. It is no good trying to turn the issue from that. This is the finding. It states at page 261:

I have carefully considered the Minister's role in this matter, having due regard to the responsibility attributable to senior departmental officers, the heavy workload which Ministers accept and the potential unfairness of looking at one issue in isolation.
In spite of these considerations, I am bound to record my view that the Minister did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively.

That is the indictment. Once that happens the Minister has got to go. In fairness to him he said 'I will leave it to the Prime Minister.' He must have been sure that nothing would happen with the Prime Minister. It is about time the Prime Minister went. When honourable members have a look at the issues that we are dealing with and see that we have many Ministers and departments in trouble is it any wonder that everybody is wondering when the next censure motion will come up?

I will revert to the present Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) and talk about the control of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. A total of $3m has gone into a bank account in Singapore. Nobody knows what has happened to it. The Auditor-General says 'Well it has disappeared'. A total of $3m has disappeared. We then come to the question of Mr Garland. Mr Garland is on record as having given $500 to some Senate candidate in the Australian Capital Territory. The police have got the $500. That was an interesting escapade. Mr Garland lost his title for a little while, came back to the Ministry and has now been promoted to the United Kingdom. If there are all these arrangements-it seems to me that the Ministers do not have to worry-is it any wonder that crime and corruption is proliferating? Let us take a look at the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Treasurer made a statement on this matter. He said: 'Look, in what is deemed to be the Perth case, the matter finished on about 3 May 1979 because there was insufficient evidence to prosecute'. If honourable members look at the Costigan report they will see that that matter did not finish. Costigan says that Mr Todman, who is from the Taxation Office, wrote an 18 page critique of what was wrong. We never heard of that matter from the Treasurer. Again, the Treasurer tells us that he was convinced that the legal advice he got was right because it was unanimous. That is a very doubtful way of judging legal advice. Admittedly he only got it from within his Department and a few other departments .

Let us again look at the Costigan report. The legal advice he was referring to was not unanimous. Following Todman's critique of the failure to prosecute, the Commissioner says that in the meantime there had been an investigation of the position in law by legal officers of the Taxation Office who generally could not understand why the existing law was not being used to redress the situation. How was it unanimous when nothing took place? We have the admission of the Treasurer that for the first time after some years he decides to get second opinion, and he gets it from the Solicitor-General. He is not a bad person to get it from because he is the second legal officer in the Commonwealth. Bearing in mind that the first officer is the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) nobody would have any reason to stick with him; they would want to go past that advice pretty rapidly. When the Treasurer went to the Solicitor-General in July of this year for the first time he is told that he could have been prosecuting under the existing law . Does the Treasurer make any reference to the McCabe-LaFranchi report about which he expressed surprise? The interesting thing about these commissions and all these investigations is that small groups of people, whether they be in San Diego or Victoria, can find all the things wrong with this Government, all the things wrong with the Ministers and, all the shonky arrangements and the massive fraud that has taken place in this case. Surely the Treasurer would have known that there was a Supreme Court action in Victoria which involved McCabe and LaFranchi? It was taken to protect one of the promoters called Commercial Securities (Vic) Pty Ltd. That is the group which was anxious to send everything to the bottom of the harbour without paying any tax. It was game enough to go to the Supreme Court in Victoria in June 1979. I would have thought that the Treasurer would have had some knowledge of that. Perhaps he would have liked to intervene in the case. Mr Justice Jenkinson in his judgment in June 1979 referred to the tax avoidance activities of Commercial Securities (Vic) Pty Ltd. He said:

. . . one of the inspectors gave evidence that the attention of officers of the Income Tax Department had been directed, at the Inspector's suggestion, by an officer of the Corporate Affairs Office to a very large pile of documents then standing in an enclosed but uncovered yard.
He said that the documents were:
. . . removed from the yard by officers of the Income Tax Department.

I would have thought that the Treasurer would have had some knowledge of that. Has there been any investigation of any of these companies? There has not. When McCabe and Lafranchi decided to investigate Mr Maher, he refused to be interviewed and the prosecution lapsed. I suggest that none of the guilty is being investigated.

All this adds up to a group of Ministers who are completely incompetent. They do not understand what they have to do. In our view they ought to get out of office. They cannot continue in office. The Prime Minister is responsible. He certainly looks after Country Party Ministers-the untouchable three. God help the Liberal back benchers. It is about time that the Government back bench had a bit of gumption, held a party meeting, had a complete spill and appointed a new ministry for the few weeks that it has left.
Motion (by Sir James Killen)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Primary Industry speaking for a period not exceeding 30 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) for his courtesy in agreeing to give me 30 minutes in which to speak. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in leading this debate earlier today used a number of quotes. He accused the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of using selective quotes. I will come back to that point later. Nobody used selective quotes more than did the Leader of the Opposition. I will deal with them appropriately during my address. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said-this needs nailing right from the start-that the discovery of horse meat in San Diego in July last year is something I should have been aware of as a result of Mr Kelly's observations. I make the point, because it is important, that Mr Kelly did not mention anything about substitution to me, nor is it mentioned in his report. The Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry found in paragraph 7.6 of its report that there was no evidence of species substitution occurring in the export trade before late 1979. The Kelly Committee finished taking evidence in November 1979. It is important to make that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us see what the Royal Commission was talking about as it affects me. Mr Justice Woodward found that, in his view, I, as Minister, did not deal adequately and effectively with aspects of the Kelly Committee report. He did not find impropriety as alleged by the Leader of the Opposition. He did not find me guilty of anything, as alleged by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. There are two aspects to this matter. One concerns the Kelly Committee report, certain statements and my action with regard to those statements. The other relates to the meeting I had in Melbourne with Mr Kelly, Mr Buettel and Mr Landos on 11 February 1980, at which Mr Kelly presented me with his report, and the conversation that took place at that meeting. The Kelly report was presented to me on 11 February 1980. It was tabled by me in the parliament just 16 days later on 27 February 1980. The whole Kelly Committee report had widespread exposure allowing for anybody to bring forward comments and observations about any aspect of it. The Kelly report in its entirety and the question of meat inspection services, as a direct follow-on from the Kelly report, was discussed by Ministers at the Australian Agricultural Council on 4 August 1980, 9 February 1981, 3 August 1981, 4 September 1981, 8 February 1982 and 26 July 1982. The chronology and history of events proves beyond any doubt whatsoever that I acted promptly and properly on the Kelly report.

One aspect that needs to be completely understood is the lack of emphasis that the Kelly Committee put on the general allegations of malpractice that it reported. In short, from any reading of the Kelly report it is abundantly clear that the Committee belived that the major and fundamental necessity was the establishment of the Australian Meat Inspection Service. On page 66 of the report, the Kelly Committee stated:
Starting a new system would give us the opportunity to turn over a new page . . .

There is one aspect of the meat industry which should be tackled with firm resolution when the new page is turned, and that is the problem of some managers trying to buy the co-operation of inspectors by giving them meat at ridiculously low prices, or countenancing excessive overtime claims, or of meat inspectors demanding cheap meat backed by the implied threat of slowing the killing chain or forcing higher offal or other condemnations if management is not complaint. AMIS legislation should include heavy punishments for administrators, VOs, meat inspectors and management who try to extract improper advantages out of the system in this manner. That this kind of practice has been too common in the past we know too well. It must be stopped in the future. We think that this exhortation applies even more to meat industry management than to the men.

Clearly, the Kelly Committee has seen the need for change but all the emphasis is on the future, when the new page is turned. In other words, it recommends getting the Australian Meat Inspection Service legislation in place first.

Mr Kelly, in his evidence before the Royal Commission, made reference to this part of his Committee's report. However, his reference excluded the phrase 'when the new page is turned'. I have to ask why that phrase was excluded. The omission places an entirely different emphasis on the paragraph. I think it is unfortunate that the Royal Commission in its references to this paragraph has also not made any reference to the sentiment about when the new page is turned. The use of those words demonstrates beyond doubt that, whatever knowledge the Kelly Committee may have had, it felt no sense of urgency. It is clear from the Kelly report that the Committee realised that the new page could not be turned immediately. On page 81 of that report, the Committee stated:

We recognise that our recommendations bristle with initial problems of implementation. Nevertheless, they do present some hope that when established and settled down, (the latter may take some time) they will lead to an elimination of the mess that at present exists . . .
That was what the Kelly Committee had to say about its own report.

I turn now to the meeting I had with Mr Kelly, Mr Buettel and Mr Landos in Melbourne on 11 February 1980. The Royal Commissioner found, even though he concedes in paragraph 1.63 that Mr Kelly and Mr Buettel when giving me their report 'did not give any specific details to the Minister when making their report' that I did not deal with allegations of cases of bribery and abuse of power in my Department in a manner that was adequate and effective. During my meeting on 11 February 1980, which lasted about 20 minutes, Mr Kelly concentrated the large bulk of his comments to me on his Australian Meat Inspection Service concept. Mr Buettel, the other Committee member, was not called to give evidence. However, I am advised that he also confirms that the meeting took about 20 minutes and dealt largely with the AMIS recommendation. He recalls that Mr Kelly also spoke in very general terms about 'a lot of nonsense around the ridges'. Certainly Mr Kelly did not make any specific allegations to me about bribery or corruption in the Commonwealth Meat Inspection Service.

Mr Kelly, under examination before the Royal Commission, admitted time and again that he had no recollection as to the precise detail of the 11 February 1980 conversation. I want to go into this aspect in some detail because this is the fundamental point in the Royal Commission argument. Mr Kelly, now a journalist and author, presented to the Royal Commission a 4 1/2-page typewritten proof of evidence. He admitted that he was assisted in the preparation of that proof of evidence by a member of the staff of the Royal Commission. The Royal Commission appears to have attached considerable importance to Mr Kelly's diary note relating to the 11 February 1980 meeting. I quote from the written proof of evidence that Mr Kelly tendered to the Commission. The note states:

11 February 1980: I went to Melbourne for the day to present Meat Report to the Minister, Peter Nixon. It was worth it because it gave me the chance to tell him a few of the notes that we could not put in the Report, such as the bribery and blackmail which is so prevalent in the meat inspection game. Poor Peter is now to see what can be done. We were gratified today to hear that the Victorian Minister of Agriculture has stated bluntly that the present situation cannot be allowed to continue. I told Nixon that both of us, Buettel and I, would be prepared to help him get something done.

There are some points that need to be made about that diary entry. Firstly, I cannot understand what Mr Kelly means when he says that the meeting gave him an opportunity to tell me 'a few of the notes that we could not put in the report'. The report mentions in broad and unspecific terms certain malpractices that the Committee found were occurring in the meat industry. If Mr Kelly had further specific information, it should have been written into his report, or he should have given me a separate detailed report-even if on a confidential basis-in writing. However, he did not go into further detail in his report, and he certainly never produced additional information for me or anyone else that I am aware of, until he appeared before the Commission.

The second point is his reference to the Victorian Minister of Agriculture having stated bluntly that the present situation cannot be allowed to continue. It could be interpreted that the Victorian Minister was referring to bribery and corruption that could not be allowed to continue. In fact, the Victorian Minister was referring to the problems connected with the dual meat inspection system that could not be allowed to continue. Mr Kelly also advised the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by telephone yesterday that it is almost certain that the statement referred to by the Victorian Minister would have related to problems of dual administration of the meat inspection service. The Kelly note then states:
I told Mr Nixon that both of us, Buettel and I, would be prepared to help him get something done.

That was a reference to helping me get something done about the establishment of an Australian meat inspection service, which was the prime recommendations of the Kelly report and the prime topic for discussion at the meeting. Those points need to be made clearly and understood when considering the Kelly diary note. What needs to be clearly understood also is that Mr Kelly's evidence to the Royal Commission, when taken in its entirety, casts very serious doubt as to the accuracy of his diary note. At the very least his diary note puts a very much stronger view of what he believes he told me on 11 February 1980 and what he admitted to the Royal Commission that he actually did tell me. The Kelly evidence needs to be considered in its entirety; the diary note has to be considered in context with the rest of Mr Kelly's evidence. It then becomes abundantly clear that there is considerable conflict between what Mr Kelly recorded in the diary note and what he actually said at the 11 February 1980 meeting. For example, Mr Kelly stated in evidence before the Royal Commission that he had no precise memory of what was said at the 11 February 1980 meeting. This appears on page 10259 of the evidence. He said that by far the most important object of the exercise-the 11 February meeting:
. . . was to explain the AMIS system . . . that was the first thing and then secondly how it hung together and what the problems were in instituting it.

He said that he did not during the Committee's hearings come across any reports or incidents of what he thought was an abuse of the use of the 'Australia Approved' stamp. He said the he was 'much more interested in the welfare of AMIS than I was of the comparatively minor skulduggery that I knew about'. He said that he did not suggest to me either at the 11 February 1980 meeting or since any definitive action beyond AMIS to overcome malpractices. He stated:
. . . if I had been asked I doubt whether I would have been able to give the specific details that a Minister would be hungry for.

He said that he did not report his findings to the police because he 'never even thought of it'. He said that he never, in his experience over the years, ever got very strong rumours that pet meat was being substituted for beef in the local and export chain.

Mr Kelly also confirmed in evidence that the rumours of skulduggery he had heard when conducting his inquiry were nothing like the rumours that were around on 7 September 1981 when he did an interview for the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program National Farm Report. In that interview, Mr Kelly was asked whether he was surprised at the magnitude of the revelations that had been made on the meat substitution issue. He replied:
Yes, I have been surprised. We were seriously conscious when doing the work that we had rumours of skulduggery and corruption but nowhere near as big as it now appears.

The overwhelming evidence is that Mr Kelly did not pass on any specific information to me. There are further examples in Mr Kelly's evidence before the Commission to back up this contention. Mr Zucker, representing the Meat Inspectors Association, asked Mr Kelly whether he thought that it would have been appropriate for the Kelly Committee to have checked allegations against inspectors. Mr Kelly replied no, and went on to explain why. He said:

What is said to the Minister is another matter, but that was the kind of talk that if I had known specific examples, which I did not, but if I had done, that would have been the proper place to talk to him privately.
Let me repeat that. Mr Kelly said:
. . . if I had known specific examples, which I did not, but if I had done, that would have been the proper place to talk to him privately.
Also, in his prepared statement to the Commission, in the paragraph preceding the quote from his diary, Mr Kelly stated:

The primary purpose of the meeting was to present the report, and any discussions held in relation to areas outside the Terms of Reference of the Committee would have been general and merely coincidental to the meeting.
Mr McPhee, counsel assisting the Royal Commission, asked Mr Kelly:

You were asked whether or not at the meeting with the Minister you provided the specific names of particular places where malpractices were said to have happened and my recollection is that you said that you either did not, or that you had no recollection of doing so. Is that correct?
Mr Kelly said:
That is right.
Mr McPhee asked:
Were you ever subequently asked by anybody from the Department for particulars of that nature?
Mr Kelly replied:

Not as far as I know. I had a discussion with some of the Departmental people and they have asked me whether I can remember. I cannot and I-it is the kind of thing I would have expected, would have thought, I would remember.
Mr Hayne, who was assisting Mr McPhee, asked Mr John Landos, the Executive Officer to the Kelly Committee who took notes during its inquiry:
Do you recall whether examples of graft or misuse of inspector power were raised at the meeting?
That is, the meeting with the Minister on 11 February 1980. Mr Landos stated:
I do not believe any specific examples were raised with the Minister.
I should emphasise here that Mr Landos was present at the meeting on 11 February 1980. Mr Stanley, representing me as the Minister for Primary Industry, asked Mr Landos:
Are you able to recall whether any specific instances of malpractice were actually mentioned by Mr Kelly to the Minister on that day?
Mr Landos replied:
No, I do not believe any specific instances were mentioned.

Let me turn now to another aspect of Mr Kelly's written submission to the Commission in which he said, according to a diary note dated 23 October 1979, that an operator from a meat establishment had told him of 'some hair-raising stories about the corruption and maladministration in DPI in Canberra as well as in the States'. At that point of his evidence, Mr McPhee interrupted Mr Kelly and asked the following question:
When you speak about corruption and maladministration in the DPI, first of all, what is the nature of the corruption you had in mind?
Mr Kelly answered:

I cannot remember specifically. This is the advantage of writing it down soon after it happens, but the disadvantage of not doing it fully. I have got a hazy recollection, it is nothing more than that, that there was something to do with the standards of building requirements that the DPI in Canberra were insisting upon, that that is what it was to do with. It was not so much much the meat inspection side of it, it was the control which the DPI correctly have in the standards of building. It was more to do with that than anything else, but I cannot be specific about what it was.
Mr McPhee asked:
Have you any recollection of what you were referring to when you spoke about production in that context?
Mr Kelly said:
No.

So that is Mr Kelly's explanation of hair raising stories-to use his words-of corruption and maladministration in the DPI in Canberra and the States. Mr Kelly , again in his written statement to the Commission, said that he would have expected 'as a result of comments made to us to Mr Nixon at the meeting of 11 February 1980, that he would have got going and straightened things out'. I will come to that matter in a minute. Mr Kelly continued:
In particular, I would have expected that the first measure he would have taken would have been to ensure security of 'Australia Approved' stamps.

As I have already indicated Mr Kelly conceded that he did not know of any abuse of the 'Australia Approved' stamp. Mr McPhee asked Mr Kelly whether he had come across any reports or incidence of what he thought was an abuse of the ' Australia Approved' stamp. Mr Kelly replied no. Given all these examples I find it hard to understand how the Commission could make the statement it has made. It seems to me that the Commission has placed immense importance on the totality of the Kelly diary notes, which were not available to me. At the same time I do not believe due consideration has been given to the totality of the evidence tendered by Mr Kelly. It also appears that the Royal Commission relied quite heavily on two other aspects in reaching its conclusion. First, was the question of my action with regard to the 11 February 1980 meeting and second, the so- called Landos notes which Mr Landos accumulated during the course of the Kelly Committee inquiries.

On the first point I have already stated, as I did before the Royal Commission, that I was concerned at Mr Kelly's allegations, broad though they were, when he spoke to me on 11 February 1980. I instructed the Director of the Bureau of Animal Health at a meeting I had with him in my office in Canberra on 18 February 1980 to contact Mr Kelly to see what other information, in particular what specific information, Mr Kelly could provide to enable further investigation to be carried out. In other words, I acted on Mr Kelly's advice just seven days after he had spoken to me. I had several meetings with Mr Gee on meat inspection in the ensuing weeks. Mr Gee told me that the Kelly allegations were too broad to be referred to the police for further investigation. That was Mr Gee's consistent advice to me and I had no reason to question that he, as the director of the Bureau of Animal Health, was advising me correctly. Despite the lack of specific information Mr Gee assured me verbally that action to safeguard against the sorts of broad allegations raised by Mr Kelly was in hand.

These assurances were supported in a written minute from Mr Gee to myself dated 15 September 1981 which I hereby table. The minute was in response to an article by Mr Alan Reid in the Bulletin dated 22 September 1981 which referred to the allegations contained in the Kelly report. It can be seen from this minute that Mr Gee did institute a number of administrative changes aimed at preventing the sorts of problems to which Mr Kelly had referred. Since that time of course the whole administrative arrangements of the meat industry have been further tightened. The point is that I did tell the Director of the Bureau of Animal Health of Mr Kelly's concerns about malpractice as he expressed them to me. I told the Director to follow them up, to contact Mr Kelly and to find out whether there was any additional information that could be useful and to get the matter fixed.

I now turn to the second point, that is to say the Landos notes. I had never heard of these notes prior to their being referred to at the Royal Commission hearing on 13 July 1982. I never knew of their existence; they were not referred to me. They are notes taken by Mr Landos in his capacity as Executive Officer to the Kelly Committee. They were taken on an in confidence basis. It is also interesting to note from the evidence of the Commission that Mr Kelly, the Chairman of the committee, also claimed that he did not know of their existence. This raises an extremely important point. I will go through it carefully. Mr Kelly in his proof of evidence to the Commission stated on page 10243 of the transcript:

During the course of the Inquiry, members of the Committee visited meat establishments throughout Australia and numerous discussions were had with persons involved in the meat industry. During those discussions, Mr Landos made notes of any relevant material to the Commission, which notes were for a period after the report was presented recorded as confidential to the Committee.
This is further supported on page 10244 when Mr Kelly said:
No record of the particular examples of graft, etc. during the inquiry would have been recorded by myself, but by Mr Landos.
Again on page 10244 Mr Kelly in his diary reference to the 11 February 1980 meeting with me stated:
It was worth it because it gave me the chance to tell him--
That is me-
A few of the notes that we could not put in the report.

Those notes must mean the Landos notes which Mr Kelly says were taken on a confidential basis. The fact is that Mr Kelly never referred to those notes at all. I will now refer to page 10267 of the Commission transcript. Mr Kelly was asked:
I take it the only notes that were taken, apart from your diary, of the Committee's proceedings, were those taken by Mr Landos?
Mr Kelly replied:
I guess so, unless Mr Buettel took some.
Mr Kelly was asked:
You did not direct that those notes be forwarded to the Minister, did you?
Mr Kelly answered:
Mr Landos' notes or mine?
The question was:
No, Mr Landos'.
Mr Kelly's reply is very important. He said:
No, I did not even know they were written until the other day.

Clearly Mr Kelly had contradicted himself on his evidence. On the one hand he said he knew of Landos taking notes as the Committee went about its inquiries; on the other hand, he said he did not even know of their existence. I have, in fact, been advised that Mr Landos sent his notes to Mr Kelly on a regular basis during the period of the inquiry. Therefore, Mr Kelly did have the notes. But at my meeting of 11 February he could have either informed me of their existence or given me a set of them on a confidential basis. But he did not do so. Another inconsistency on Mr Kelly's part is also worthy of mention at this point. On page 10244 of the transcript Mr Kelly stated:
However, I find that I have recorded in my diary the following comments which would have been the basis of my own observations to Mr Nixon in this regard.
Page 10267 of the transcript shows that Mr Kelly was asked:
At the time you saw the Minister in February did you have your diary with you?
Mr Kelly replied:
No, that is not the kind I hasten to carry around with me; I might lose it.

While he said that his diary 'would have been the basis of my observations to Mr Nixon', in fact it was not. Mr Kelly did not have his diary with him when he met me. The evidence clearly shows that no information of the type contained in the diary was ever given to me. I turn now to the so-called Landos notes. The Royal Commission has clearly placed considerable importance on the Landos notes. For example, Mr Justice Woodward stated:
Senior officers of the Department had available to them a good deal of detailed information which was not passed on to the Minister.
He also said:

Mr Landos had taken summary notes which included references to particular allegations of malpractices including the manipulation of overtime, stealing, the provision of cheap and free meat, and the obtaining of concessions by inspectors by the enforcement of ridiculous standards.
He further stated:
Information concerning the specific instances upon which the Committee had formed its general impression was available to anyone wishing to seek it out.

The point must be made and I will repeat it: The information was not available to me. I did not even know of the existence of the Landos notes. Mr Landos, in his evidence before the Commission on 13 July 1982, stated that the Committee, of which he was a part, regarded this information as confidential. He also told the Commission that he did make the information available to departmental officers 'at a later stage', which was 'two or three months after the Committee reported'. The fact is, however, that the Landos notes never reached my desk. I could not act upon them because I did not know of their existence.

Given all this, the question arises: On what basis could I refer anything to the Australian Federal Police or to any other authority for greater investigation? The only course open to me was the one that I followed, namely, to call in the Director of the Bureau of Animal Health, tell him what Mr Kelly had told me and direct him to follow the matter up. That is what I did. As it transpires Mr Gee did not contact Mr Kelly directly. He chose instead to speak to Mr Landos. Mr Gee stated in evidence before the Commission:

I went to Mr Landos and inquired of him as to what evidence, what data, they did have from their hearings, and from their conversations and from the submissions they raised and John Landos related to me that there was nothing substantial, that there was nothing of what we would call hard evidence, and I said 'Are you sure there is nothing that would warrant us investigating further or going to the police?' and he was of the opinion that there was not anything of that nature.
Furthermore, Mr Hayne, for counsel assisting the Commission suggested to Mr Gee:
It was clear that the Committee itself had made fairly strong statements in its report on a number of specific practices, had they not?
To that Mr Gee answered:

The Committee in fact in its report made very few references to administrative practices. In fact, in a roughly 100 page report there are two or three paragraphs that only relate to issues of this nature.

Mr Landos produced a minute, dated 21 February 1980, which was not referred to me, and in which he stated that the Committee members, in their meeting with me on 11 February 1980, expressed strong views as to the 'sordid' nature of the meat inspection service. As I have said, Mr Gee followed up my request for further information on the state of the meat inspection service by discussing it with Mr Landos. Mr Gee was questioned about this at the Royal Commission. He denied that Mr Landos had expressed any strong views about the so-called sordid nature of the meat inspection service. Mr Gee stated:
Mr Landos did not support an attitude of strong views in later discussions with me.
Mr Gee also told the Commission:

I do not have the view, even now, that they (Buettel and Kelly) expressed strong views (at the 11 February 1980 meeting) and I did not have the view then that they expressed strong views. If they had expressed really strong views, I am sure they would have been taken more notice of.
Mr Landos also seems to support this view because when referring to the credibility of the information contained in the notes he had gathered, he told the Royal Commission:
By far the great majority, if not all of the allegations received by the Committee, were based on rumour or on secondhand evidence.

I now return to the Royal Commission's findings. It has stated that I did not deal with the allegation that there had been cases of bribery and abuse of power in my Department in a manner that was adequate and effective. The point about this statement is that at no time was any such allegation put before me in such direct and forthright terms. Indeed, I was not told of any allegation that even nears that situation or interpretation. I therefore must question paragraph 1.64 of the report, which reads:

But I believe that the Minister, having heard from a responsible source that there had been cases of bribery and abuse of power in his Department, should have taken positive steps to investigate the matter. In my view he did not deal with this allegation in a manner that was adequate and effective.

As I have stated, both here and before the Royal Commission, and as has been conformed in evidence before the Commission by Mr Kelly, Mr Landos and Mr Gee, I was provided with no specific information. And Mr Justice Woodward himself found in his report, in paragraph 2.34, that much of the information supplied initially on malpractice was 'little better than rumour'. Furthermore, Mr Justice Woodward himself has pointed to the difficulty of getting concrete information about malpractice in the meat industry. In his paragraph 2.75, he states:

If this Report had been written in April of this year instead of September, on the basis of evidence then available, I would have reported that malpractice in the industry was rare, and felt compelled to recommend that, in the light of that finding, many of the present security measures were unnecessary and that no fundamental change in administrative arrangements was required to prevent or detect malpractices.

(Extension of time granted). This is one of the things that the Leader of the Opposition accused the Prime Minister of selectively quoting. As the Leader of the Opposition put it, the words that followed-'Such a report would have been totally misleading'-were not added. I accuse the Leader of the Opposition of selective quoting. The words 'Such a report would have been totally misleading' refer to the totality of that page, because the later evidence that came out after April demonstrated that the conclusion he would have reached in April would have been unsatisfactory. So it is not the Prime Minister who selectively quoted; it is the Leader of the Opposition who selectively quoted. Let us be clear on that. The Royal Commission had sat, full time, from the time of its appointment until April-a period of seven months-before it began to see the light of day as to what was really going on with this industry. That is a significant fact.

I now turn to aspects of the Royal Commissioner's report dealing with the meat substitution issue of August last year, and the subsequent Government action. The first point to make is to repeat the Royal Commissioner's finding in paragraph 1.19:
Returning to the Department of Primary Industry, it is only fair to say that, under instructions from its Minister, it acted promptly and effectively when the meat substitution scandal erupted.
That is a major finding of the Royal Commission. And, in paragraph 1.20, it states:

The steps taken were drastic, but appropriate to the situation . . . the Department did succeed in restoring the confidence of the USDA in a comparatively short time and without excessive disruption or cost to the Australian industry.
And, in paragraph 1.22, it states:

I believe that, in consequence of the strong reaction of the Minister and the Department, and the establishment of this Royal Commission, the current level of malpractice in the meat industry is lower than it ever has been. This desirable situation should be vigorously maintained.

Those findings by the Royal Commissioner put the lie to the Opposition's claims that the Government, or I as Minister, was slow to act on the meat substitution issue. Let me cite another example. Paragraph 7.2 of the Commissioner's report states:
I should say at the outset that I have no doubt that the industry has never been more free of malpractices than it is today.
The Royal Commissioner also says in paragraph 1.61:
Generally, such matters as were referred to Commonwealth Ministers were dealt with adequately and effectively.
And, in paragraph 8.39, he states:
Insofar as allegations were reported by the Department to Mr Nixon, I do not consider any criticism can be levelled at his handling of them.
The only point of criticism that the Royal Commission has stated of me is in paragraph 8.39, which reads:
The only possible criticism of his handling of his responsibilities in this area relates to his reaction to the Report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry in 1980.

I have dealt with that statement. However, notwithstanding its inaccuracy, I considered that such a statement coming from a royal commission was a serious matter. The Commission had reflected on my handling not of the meat substitution issue, but of one aspect of the Kelly report. I received a copy of the Royal Commission report at 2.45 on Friday afternoon. After reading it I immediately contacted the Prime Minister and offered my resignation. I confirmed my intention to him in a letter which I delivered personally to the Prime Minister on Sunday afternoon.

Last night, after considering all the facts of the report, the Prime Minister decided not to accept my resignation. I thank him for that. I do not believe that I have in any way neglected my responsibilities in the handling of any matters raised by Mr Justice Woodward. I should point out that I was prepared to accept whatever decision the Prime Minister reached and continue to serve the Government and the Prime Minister with total and undivided loyalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone listening to this debate tonight would think that the only issue is whether the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) should have accepted the sham offer to resign of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon)-or should I say in respect of this Government, the almost refreshing offer to resign. Anyone listening to the debate would think that Australia's livestock and meat industries had not been put in jeopardy by this Government, that a trade of over $1 billion a year had not been put at risk and that indeed there had been no meat substitution. Anyone would think that the whole debate is about poor old Bert Kelly. The last book he wrote was entitled One More Nail, and we have seen all the nails thudding in tonight. The public must be rather mystified. This report is about meat substitution. The Opposition is censuring the Prime Minister because it is he who is setting inconsistent, improper standards of ministerial responsibility for his Ministers. Twenty-two Ministers have either been sacked or have resigned and a different standard applies to National Country Party Ministers. The public, the primary producers and the parliamentarians want to know when a Minister is ever responsible for what happens in departments under his control. It is not only the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who is involved in this case; there is also the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman).

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's speech earlier today was an apologia for the Minister for Primary Industry. It was a concoction, a Clarence Darrow defence of the indefensible, a contrived legalistic defence involving the bucketing of all concerned in the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. The Prime Minister was trying to show, as was the Minister for Primary Industry, that we can have smoke but no fire. It shows that the offered resignation of the Minister for Primary Industry was a sham. Obviously when he went to the Prime Minister or discussions were held they said: 'Here is the problem; what is the best way to get out of it?' The Prime Minister is desperately searching for scapegoats because of his Government's hopeless management of the economy. This report shows that he, his Government and his Ministers are not only bad economic managers but also incompetent administrators . The debate today has boiled down to a case of Nixon versus Kelly and Woodward. I have a sense of deja vu. It is like the debate about a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the Sinclair versus Rae committee. In both cases the Government has argued that the findings, in one case those of a Senate Committee and in this case those of the Royal Commissioner, are wrong. That is what it is arguing. The Prime Minister engaged in selective quoting, and we have now heard from the Minister for Primary Industry that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) also engaged in selective quoting. When we have a report this big there is no way in which people cannot engage in selective quoting. In no time at all the debate boils down to a slanging match point for point and each person leaves out the paragraph he wants to leave out. I am not going to read all the relevant paragraphs; I simply say that the guts of the matter in terms of the Minister are in paragraphs 1.63, 1. 64, 8.45, 8.46, 8.47 and 8.48.

I want to talk about the fact that the Government is not treating the delivery of this report in the same spirit that it exhibited when it set up the Royal Commission. This report is not all about Bert Kelly and Mr Landos's notes. The Government has not addressed itself to the positive recommendations of the Royal Commission. It has not addressed itself to the allegations. Let us just look at some of the malpractices. Let us for a moment just get back to the meat industry . The Commissioner said that all the malpractices were done for financial gain. Local meat was being sent into the export trade; pet meat was being put into meat for human consumption. Some did not follow health regulations, some did. There were false descriptions in terms of age and quality. In terms of the el- Hal slaughter there has been bribery and forgery of certificates. The Royal Commissioner says that the reputation of the Australian meat industry was well below that of New Zealand. There were the allegations of robbing the pack; taking out the best cuts but not saying so. Australian approved stamps were lost and there was no attempt to find them; slaughter dates were wrong, boxes were relidded to change the date; transfer certificates were forged and meat was moved from one store to the other; and export documentation was not obtained. This is what Mr Justice Woodward is finding. This Government is saying that no- one, certainly not a Minister, is responsible for this.

This is a quite impossible situation. The debate is not about poor old Bert Kelly; it is about the meat industry. I do not have the time to read into Hansard the recommendations but again I refer honourable members to the full list in Chapter 9. There are over 17 pages of recommendations. I would have thought that the Prime Minister or the Minister for Primary Industry, who allegedly exhibit some responsibility or interest in this area, would have at least mentioned that. The Prime Minister apparently regards the cattle industry as being incidental to the findings of the Royal Commission. As I have said before, the Royal Commission was set up to investigate the crisis in which this Government's hopeless administration had placed the cattle and meat industries. The National Country Party Ministers in charge of primary industry in this country had jeopardised our entire meat industry's export trade.

So today the Prime Minister came in to give the reasons why he had saved the head of the Minister for Primary Industry and engaged in some selective quoting. Let us put that aside and look at the people he bucketed in turn. He bucketed the Department of Primary Industry, the Commonwealth meat inspectors, the Bureau of Animal Health and the Australian Federal Police. The Minister for Administrative Services has not offered to resign over the matter involving the Australian Federal Police but he is a Liberal Party member so he is not game; it would be accepted. Then there has been Mr Kelly and finally there is Mr Justice Woodward himself. All these groups and individuals got a bucketing.

Yet the Prime Minister has the gall to say that the Public Service is sometimes maligned when it should not be. That is rather strange, coming from the Liberals . When it suited him today the Prime Minister praised some parts of the Public Service, but on balance his speech was a litany of contrivances, smears, abuse and innuendo relating to public servants. I think it is rather obvious that Bert Kelly was stood over but would not budge. It is the same thing that happened to the now Mr Justice Ellicott in 1975, except that Bert did not budge. The Prime Minister has now said that there is to be an inquiry into the Public Service. This is just a silly diversion. Surely the Royal Commission into Australian Government Administration provided enough of that. I hope that Mr Kelly will stand up for himself in this matter and not take the drubbing that he has taken here today. I understand that he has just appeared on Nationwide and said that the Minister took no notice of the charges of malpractice that Mr Kelly relayed to him. Mr Kelly did not give book, chapter and verse of the allegations; he conducted an investigation into the dual meat inspection service that necessarily entailed his looking at the meat industry in this country. Kelly came across many allegations of bribery, corruption and malpractices and he reported these to the Minister. Mr Justice Woodward has said that the Minister did not act on those things effectively or adequately. This Government has engaged in nonsense. It has set up a Commission, and because it does not like a handful of paragraphs in the report and the report does not suit it politically it rubbishes it. Of course the report does not suit this Prime Minister. Goodness gracious me, when his Treasurer, his Attorney-General and his Minister for Defence are all under a shadow and then his Minister for Primary Industry also comes under a shadow, of course he has to duck for cover. But if this is the way in which we are to treat royal commissions it brings the whole rationale for setting them up into great doubt.

This Royal Commission met for almost a year. The Royal Commissioner is a distinguished judge. He was head of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. That gave him good experience even to understand the National Country Party and its deviousness. But the Prime Minister has examined this report over the weekend and come into the House with an exercise of not looking at the report or the cattle and the meat industries, but at ways and means of protecting this Minister. That, of course, is symptomatic of this rotten, corrupt Government. The central issue is ministerial responsibility and the failure of this Prime Minister to live up to his high-minded words on that concept. I do not suppose one can say that the Kelly versus Nixon thing is a footnote but it is not central to this issue other than in purely political terms, in terms of the day to day discourse in the Parliament. We have to look at some of the more long term things-the cattle industry, the meat industry and ministerial responsibility. Let us just take some of these high minded quotations. The Leader of the Opposition has quoted the classic one from the Prime Minister, which is now shown to be absolute humbug. Let us take the statements of the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) when he was Minister for Primary Industry. Here is a quotation from him:

From my point of view a principal consideration is that the ADI is a wholly owned subsidiary of the corporation and as such I am directly responsible for its activities to the Commonwealth Parliament.

That statement was made by the Minister for Defence when he was Minister for Primary Industry. It was contained in a letter to the Australian Dairy Corporation Chairman, Mr Webster, on 20 April 1979, which appears in the report of the Auditor-General's first inquiry into the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong ) Ltd. He was saying that he lived up to some idea of his ministerial responsibility in that regard. But this Minister will not live up to his. This has been a massive scandal. It has been worse than the ADI one in a way, although I am finding it hard to work out which is the worst. There was international tax evasion, and a breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and poor old Bill Pyle was made a scapegoat because he disconnected his speedo. Well, it is not Pyle who is the scapegoat this time; it is poor old Bert Kelly. The Government has not acted in a responsible way to protect Australia's billion dollar cattle industry. That was the whole problem at the outset. When the scandal broke this Government did not know which way to go. First of all, half of the Ministry thought their mates were involved and the other half did not know whom to phone to find out what the issue was all about.

There have been a lot of statements by the Prime Minister today to the effect that nothing was known-he quoted paragraph 7.6 of the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry-about meat substitution before late 1979. I put it to honourable members that the allegations go back to 1975. Put aside Bert Kelly's allegations and report to the Minister. There have been widespread allegations, over a prolonged period, about malpractice in the Australian meat industry involving the domestic and export markets. I will not take an extreme position. I acknowledge it would be impossible for a government to respond to all the isolated allegations which are made and which, on the whole, are difficult to prove. Responding to all such allegations would result in a government chasing a large number of non-events; but, even so, there have been allegations of malpractice in the meat industry. These can be documented over six years. The allegations come from a wide variety of sources and relate to nearly all aspects of the meat industry.

We know that these allegations reached the Government from the time of the first publicly documented complaint in 1975. Following the only successful prosecution-in fact the only prosecution-of a company involved in malpractice relating to export meat shipments in January 1980 the Cattle Council of Australia pressed three times for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to request that the Department of Primary Industry impose stricter penalties on companies found guilty of malpractice. No action was taken by the AMLC. Why not? The Government should have been aware of the Cattle Council's call for stricter penalties, at least through its representative on the AMLC, but why did it take no action? In view of the persistence of the allegation of malpractice, the successful prosecution of one company and industry calls for stricter penalties, the Government's continued stand of ignoring the allegation moved from misjudgment to criminal negligence, given the seriousness of the charges in terms of potential consequences for Australia's multimillion dollar meat industry.

Despite six years of warning that something was the matter in the Australian meat industry, when the story of the discovery of horseflesh in the United States finally broke, the Government had no plan of action. The Government even failed to act earlier on a report it had commissioned into meat inspection in Australia. That is the Kelly report; and I will not go into that. But with glaring loopholes in Australia's meat inspection service and with evidence of malpractice in all areas of the meat trade unfolding day by day, when the United States discovery was reported, the Government sat looking silly until the United States Department of Agriculture took the initiative. Why could not the Australian Government have taken the lead then? It was already late in the day but perhaps it was not too late.

I do not have time to refer to the various aspects of the way this story developed, but I can refer to some of the events and set the chronology for honourable members. In 1975 a complaint was made to the Victorian Department of Agriculture that meat for local consumption was being falsely labelled as export quality and shipped to the United States. The information was passed to the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry. The Commonwealth Police investigated the matter and its findings were submitted to the Department of Primary Industry. The evidence was deemed to be insufficient and prosecutions were not launched. In 1977, just prior to the elections, Senator Primmer told the then Minister of allegations about improper practices. The result was no action. In December 1977 the Victorian Attorney-General told of allegations that meat being slaughtered for local consumption was being illegally transferred to cold stores and shipped overseas. The allegations were passed to the Commonwealth Police. In January 1978, Richmond Councillor Alexander wrote to the Prime Minister to express concern at the allegations. He was advised that the Commonwealth Police were investigating the matter.

In March 1978 Senator Primmer made a statement to the Senate detailing certain allegations. These allegations are reported at page 404 of Hansard of 7 March 1978. Nothing has happened. (Extension of time granted). In March 1978 Senator Primmer made a statement detailing allegations to the Senate. He named names. Nothing happened. Nobody from the Commonwealth Police, the Government or the Department of Primary Industry ever approached him for further information. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) now claims that he knew nothing of the Primmer statement. We have to ask: Where was he? In June 1979 the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union newsletter detailed allegations of corrupt abattoir operators and meat inspectors passing sub-standard meat for export. Again nothing happened, other than the AMIEU being advised to keep its mouth shut or the jobs of its members would be affected. In November 1979 Mr Williams, a Liberal Member of the Victorian Legislative Assembly for Doncaster-I would not put much faith in his evidence-alleged that meat prepared for local consumption had been illegally transferred for export. The police actually investigated the matter but no charges were laid.

In January 1980, after an 18-month delay, before the Department of Primary Industry granted permission to the Australian Federal Police to prosecute, W. Pope & Co. Pty Ltd was convicted of falsely labelling diced mutton as diced beef in shipments to the Middle East. The fine was $100. In late 1980 there was a meeting between Australian Federal Police and three of Australia's major meat exporters concerned at the breakdown in the fragmented meat inspection system, the replacement of export by local products, and the substitution of horseflesh for beef. There was no action. In July 1981 horseflesh was found in a shipment of Australian beef to the United States.

I would like to have the time to relate the whole sorry story to the House about what happened from then on. The point I am making is that the statement of the Prime Minister, in which he quoted from paragraph 7.6, saying that there was no evidence of substitution before late 1979, cannot be substantiated. The Opposition quite plainly disagrees with the finding in that paragraph. There was plenty of smoke and there was plenty of fire about all of these matters. Perhaps I could refer to what happened at that time and how this Minister let down the Government and the beef industry. This matter first attracted wide publicity when the meat was detected in the United States in July last. In the Age newspaper of 9 July last year it was stated that the State authorities in Victoria planned to close loopholes allowing substitution of kangaroo meat in fast foods on the domestic market. What was the response from this Government? There was none. On 13 August the National Farm Report stated that Federal Police were called in to investigate claims by the United States that horsemeat had been found-600 lb of it. An export ban was placed on Profreeze and seven other companies. The Government's response was that there was still some doubt about where the horsemeat came from-Australia or the United States-but after a few days it imposed an export ban on Profreeze. On 14 August there was a claim by the New South Wales Livestock and Grain Producers Association Secretary, Mr Brown, that beef exports were being deliberately discredited by the United States. What was the reaction from the Government? There was none.

I can continue to refer to the events including Wally Curran's Mafia claims. Dr Bill Gee of the Bureau of Animal Health pointed out on 15 August that it was almost certain that the bogus beef came from Australia and substitution took place in Australia. The Department of Primary Industry attempted to talk to a man named Hammond. I can continue to relate these actions day by day as the sorry story unfolded. The Minister did nothing until 26 August when the United States Department of Agriculture set the new standards for Australian beef. The Minister had not acted from some time in July until 26 August. That is why the Opposition, in a censure motion at that time, said that the Government was acting in a very dilatory fashion on such a very important issue.

I do not know who wrote today's script. The Leader of the Opposition terms the Government's front bench as 'Horgan's heros'. But I think this matter reminds me more of Yes Minister. Both those shows are comedies. But we are not talking about a comedy; we are talking about a farce-a tragedy. This matter is symptomatic of what is going on in this rotten, scandal-ridden government. The Government cannot act when it is faced by a crisis because its administration of its key departments is so shocking that it does not know what to do. We are not looking only at the Minister for Primary Industry in this censure motion but also at all the Ministers who have resigned, have been forced to resign or have been sacked. We are looking particularly at this time at the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) both of whom are involved in a lack of ministerial duty as far as the problem of tax evasion is concerned.

For all those reasons, I believe that any fair-minded person listening to what has been put here today will back the Opposition and censure the Prime Minister for his inability to maintain ministerial responsibility in his Government, thereby causing this widespread malpractice and corruption. This Government is composed of Ministers who are not only bad economic managers but also bad administrators. This Government was responsible for putting Australia's meat export trade, which is worth over $1 billion, at risk. The meat substitution scandal did occur. The Government cannot say to the people, the Australia meat industry and to the cattle producers that no one is to blame, least of all the Minister for Primary Industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and Acting Attorney- General)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a travesty of justice to condemn the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) on what we have heard today. This censure motion, which is really against the Minister for Primary Industry, has no substance whatsoever. It is extraordinary that it should ever have been contemplated, and it should be rejected. I understand that I am the last speaker on the Government side in this debate and I think it is appropriate that I try to put things into perspective and sum up exactly what the arguments are. That will have the attraction, whilst not going over all the same ground, of enabling us to take a bird's eye view of the matter and see exactly where we are, what are the allegations against the Minister and what is the response. The first point that should be made is that it would be a travesty of justice to condemn the Minister for Primary Industry on what has been put against him today in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I think there are several basic points that I should make and we should understand. The first is that, or my part and the part of everyone on the Government side, there is certainly no intention to pass any personal criticism on either Mr Justice Woodward or the Honourable C. R. Kelly, a former member of this House. That should be clearly understood because of certain remarks made about Government speakers today. There has been no attempt or intention to pass any personal criticism on either of those gentlemen. The second point is equally important; that is, that a royal commission report is not a judgment on individuals, but it is regarded, apparently, by some people these days as exactly that, as a judgment on individuals.

If it is to be regarded as a judgment on individuals and if people are to be condemned on the basis of a royal commission report then we, in defence, are entitled to do two things. The first thing we are entitled to do is to analyse the evidence and see whether the evidence comes up to scratch and whether it justifies the conculusions reached by the Royal Commissioner. The second thing we are entitled to do is to analyse the Royal Commissioner's report and submit it to very close scrutiny indeed to see whether his conclusions come up to scratch. I believe that one can do that without making any personal criticisms of the Royal Commissioner or the witnesses who appeared before him.

That is what we have to do here. We have to analyse the evidence and see whether it justifies condemning or censuring the Minister and to analyse the report of the Royal Ccmmission into the Australian Meat Industry and see whether those conclusions which are adverse to the Minister are justified. The Government says that if one analyses the evidence fairly one would not condemn or censure the Minister for Primary Industry and that if one analyses the Royal Commissioner's report one is entitled to say, as the Government does with great vehemence, that it does not justify criticism, condemnation or censure of the Minister. Without going over all the detail-I promised that I would not do that- I say in generality that one can look at this matter and the allegations about the Minister in two ways. The first way is to accept everything that was said in the Royal Commissioner's report at face value and reach conclusions on that. The second way one can approach it is to look at all the evidence and see what conclusions one reaches oneself. No matter which way one approaches the matter, the Minister should not be condemned or censured.

Let us take the first way. Let us assume for the purposes of the present argument that everything that is said in the Royal Commissioner's report should be taken at face value and is accurate in every way, without making any criticisms of the report and without using the evidence at all. What do we find then? We find in the first place that the allegations that the Minister was supposed to have investigated-I emphasise that this is not arguing about the evidence; it is taking it on face value-were themselves unsubstantiated and were allegations of the most general nature without names or places, that they were not specific. The second thing we find is that the importance attached to them can be seen by the way the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems treated the allegations. They were clearly a minor part of the Kelly report and were not the reason for the Committee conducting its inquiries.

The third thing we can conclude very readily, again without arguing about the evidence but taking it all at face value, taking all of the statements in the Royal Commissioner's report as gospel truth, is that it is clear from the evidence upon which the Royal Commissioner relied that the allegations were pursued by the Minister. I do not think, in fairness, that that point has been made with anything like the clarity that it should have been made in this debate today. When one reads the evidence one cannot but conclude that the Minister did examine these allegations. That is the situation taking the first approach of accepting the Royal Commissioner's report at face value.

Accepting all that the Royal Commissioner said, the case against the Minister can be summed up in this way: He did not deal adequately with some allegations- some general and vague allegations, unsubstantiated and with no detail as to who should be investigated, and allegations on matters that the Committee was not even investigating. In any event-I come back to the basic point-it is clear from the report that the allegations were pursued. Before I go on from that point, I wish to make the fundamental point that from beginning to end there was not a single allegation of time, place or person which was put to the Minister and which it could be said could have been examined or pursued.

That is the way we put it on the first basis. If one accepts the Royal Commissioner's report at face value, if one makes no criticisms of the report and if one does not point to evidence that he overlooked, one comes to the conclusion that, on the basis of what the Royal Commissioner said, the Minister for Primary Industry should not be censured or condemned. I turn now to the second way of approaching the matter. I believe, in defence of the Minister, that the case is much stronger when one looks at the facts and the whole of the evidence. When the whole of the evidence is examined the Minister is indeed in a much stronger position.

Let us look at the complete picture, which unfortunately is not revealed in the report. The full picture is seen only when the evidence is examined. The report of a royal commission, as I said before, is wrongly regarded these days as something of a judgment-in this case a judgment on the Minister and his conduct. But this judgment-if that is the way we are going to refer to it-in the first place omits all reference to the evidence of two witnesses who were concerned in the Minister's trial, if that is the way it is going to be regarded, because the judgment omits reference to the Minister's own evidence and the details of what he did to follow up these allegations and it omits the evidence of Mr Gee, who took a major part in these proceedings. It not only ignores and fails to make any reference to Mr Gee's evidence and gives inadequate reference to the Minister's evidence-I might say evidence on oath-but also makes some very grave errors in reproducing the evidence, because the erroneous extracts from the Kelly report and the evidence, I believe, are used to justify a conclusion that is adverse to the Minister.

No reference is made to the evidence of those witnesses and no reference was made to that evidence which could be used in defence of the Minister. That is why I believe it is so subject to criticism. It is bad enough for a royal commission to make errors in evidence and to set out wrongly extracts from a report-this is the basis for the attempt to condemn the Minister-but it is doubly bad when that is the very case which is put against him. Also-this makes it even worse-if one sets out the evidence word for word as it really was in the Kelly report, one finds that the Minister has a very good defence indeed. That is why I believe it is subject to criticism. What were the facts? Mr Kelly presented his report.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was never put to him.

—As the Leader of the House says, that was never put to him. I come to the facts. Mr Kelly presented his report. He had a conversation with the Minister when he presented his report. Honourable members should not forget, if we are using the court room analogy, that Mr Kelly in fact is the main witness against the Minister. When Mr Kelly was giving his evidence he was asked what the conversation was about. He was asked for details. What did he say? I do not think this has been mentioned in the debate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am under oath so I do not know what I said.

The Opposition is asking us to condemn the Minister for Primary Industry on the basis of Mr Kelly putting to the Minister at a meeting allegations of bribery and corruption. What happened when the main witness was asked what the details of the allegations were? He said:
I am under oath so I do not know what I said.
But when he gets down to some detail he said:
We had rumours of skullduggery and corruption but nowhere near as big as it now appears.

If there were any thought that Mr Kelly regarded these rumours as being of any substance or constituting anything that should be investigated, surely that is put at rest by his evidence. He was asked what sort of details he had. He said:
. . . I doubt whether I would have been able to give the specific details that a Minister would be hungry for.
Not only does Mr Kelly not remember what he said but also, even if he had been asked about the details of the allegations, he would have to say:
. . . I doubt whether I would have been able to give the specific details that a Minister would be hungry for.
On page 10275 he said:
That is right.

He said that in answer to a question suggesting that he did not really provide specific names of places where malpractices were said to have happened. It is said by the Opposition-let there be no doubt that this is the basis of the case against the Minister-that it is on the very basis of what Mr Kelly said to the Minister at the meeting in February 1980 that the Minister should have investigated these allegations. But when we come to the main witness the Opposition produces in support of those allegations we find that the witness cannot remember what he said. He did not give any specific allegations. The most he can say is that there were rumours of skulduggery and such like.

I come back to the basic point I made at the beginning of my remarks. It would be a travesty of justice to censure or condemn the Minister on that sort of evidence. Not only is that bad enough but also, I venture to say-I repeat that I make no criticisms of the Royal Commissioner in person-that if the Opposition is going to censure or condemn a Minister and if a report is going to be presented, as the Royal Commissioner did, is it too much to ask that the Royal Commissioner accurately quote from the Kelly report, as he places so much of his case against the Minister on the Kelly report? But there are substantial and serious omissions in those parts of the Kelly report which the Royal Commissioner sets out in his report. It would be a travesty to condemn or censure the Minister when that is the treatment given to evidence against him. The Kelly report did not say that legislation should include heavy punishments for this sort of misconduct. It said:
AMIS-
That is, the Australian Meat Inspection Service-
legislation should include heavy punishments . . .

It is plain, when one reads the Kelly report, that what Mr Kelly and his Committee were saying to the Minister in that report was not that there were malpractices which the Minister should investigate. The Kelly Committee said that there was a need for a new inspection service and that when the new inspection service was set up by legislation heavy penalties should be imposed for this sort of malpractice. Frankly, it would be very unfair indeed-a travesty -to censure or condemn the Minister on the basis of that material. I would have thought that it was not too much to expect that a royal commission about its task would quote accurately from the Kelly report, if it is the Kelly report which is used as the basis for criticising the Minister's performance of his ministerial functions.

I said at the outset that one can approach this matter in two ways. One can accept the report at face value and see what conclusions come from that. If one does that, without even looking at the evidence-simply accepting what the Royal Commissioner says-the conclusion that the Minister should be censured is not justified. Alternatively, one can approach the matter in what I would say is the way royal commission reports have to be approached these days-that is, regard it as a judgment. If one regards it as a judgment one should look at the evidence to see whether justice can be done. One should look at the evidence to see whether conclusions are reached. On either basis, the Minister should not be censured.
