TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, when I last spoke in this debate on Wednesday night I mentioned the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and the inability of that inquiry to probe properly and give correct estimates of what might have been lost through tax avoidance. There were many estimates of what was lost through tax avoidance and evasion. The report itself, which is unpublished, has not named the people who would be caught under the provisions of the anti- avoidance legislation that is already enacted, in the natural course of assessment. Some of the names in the Costigan report would be those of years ago , before the 1980 legislation took place. Some, I believe, would refer back to the Australian Labor Party's term in office, before anti-avoidance legislation was in force. A little-made observation in the whole Costigan affair is that Mr Costigan was appointed by a conservative Federal Government and a conservative Victorian State Government and had his terms of reference widened to look at the whole tax avoidance question. If there is to be a question on this, it certainly cannot be as to our Government's integrity in wanting to bring everything to the surface. Without a doubt they are the actions of a government that is determined to come to grips with not only the tactics of the Painters and Dockers Union but also the whole tax avoidance industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I defy the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) to substantiate the figures he so carelessly broadcast in the hope that they would fall on fertile imaginations . One claim that he has not been able to substantiate was in relation to the three knights in Queensland whom he has not named. In fact, he has reneged on this. This only indicates the shallowness of his comments and his allegations. In fact no one, not even Mr Costigan, can quote the total figure that has been lost or disputed through tax avoidance or tax evasion. If the work of the Special Prosecutor that this Government has now appointed, armed with the present and proposed legislation of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), is to be rewarded I suggest that the eventual cost in tax avoidance will be shown to be absolutely minimal and only a fraction of the figure mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition.

When it comes to tax evasion, that is another matter altogether. This matter is being confused by the claims of the Opposition, which are not specific. I have claimed in the past that there is a significant area of tax loss through tax evasion. This involves wages, salaries and allowances that are undeclared, interest that is unrecorded, income from sales that is not recorded and, of course, the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. This is tax evasion. It should not be confused at all with tax avoidance. The tax evasion question has been deliberately interlocked by Labor with tax avoidance to associate the whole lot with the wealthy and the companies of Australia. But the major portion of the loss is caused by the significant number of Australians who are abusing the taxation system-high and low income earners alike. The accusations, the rhetoric and the false assumptions made by the Opposition leave the Opposition floundering in its own cesspool of guilt. That is fair enough.

The underground economy has distorted all the economic calculations we use today on the employed, the unemployed, the gross national product, the revenue forgone, the productivity of Australia and even our standards of living. How can one ascertain a living standard when a lot of the income that is derived in Australia has gone underground and is not recorded? All such statistics, in comparison with 10 years ago, are virtually worthless because of the effect of this cash or underground economy. In some instances those who defraud the tax collectors are, in a way, defrauding the welfare and service system. They include those who draw unemployment relief and have a job under another name and those who receive health and education grants or rebates when they earn undisclosed and untaxed income. The position undoubtedly is getting worse and is of tremendous concern, or should be, to every Australian.

In my electorate of Dawson people claim that there are instances of one person using up to six names in trying to get established identification for the receipt of goods. This indicates that one person might be holding various jobs under different names and/or drawing unemployment relief or other grants in more than one name. Only two weeks ago, in Sydney, following a person dying at a rather young age, it was disclosed that he had 15 aliases and had been collecting 15 unemployment cheques. This is the type of abuse that is going on. There are instances of seasonal workers insisting on cash in hand amd payments under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme being made on false declarations of income from the parents. There are those who seek universal health and hospital cover at public expense while being able to earn money. They live very comfortably on those who pay their legitimate taxes and their health insurance and for their children's further education.

I heard of an instance recently in which 64 persons who were registered for employment were written to by an office of the Commonwealth Employment Service in preparation for jobs that would become available. Only 12 of those 64 people responded. One half had other employment or were out of town and only three were available for work-5 per cent of the total. That is an appalling result. As I understand the present system, the Department of Social Security runs its own relief program and there is little or no liaison with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The system now involves two departments with separate inspectoral staff, one trying to maintain a register of unemployment and the other paying funds to the unemployed. It is a further receipe for defrauding the welfare system and providing few checks on the registered unemployed. It is an encouragement for staff of both offices to bend before the pressure and go the path of least resistance and pay out unnecessarily and not insist on proper work test conditions. As I see it, the welfare bill is rising because of fraud. Unemployment is overstated, not understated as the Opposition so gloriously declares, again pulling figures from the sky. Proper tax is not being paid by a significant portion of Australian income earners. It is the completely intolerable and worsening fraud in the financial system that the Government must address itself to, not tax evasion alone.

The United States of America, the bastion of free enterprise and expression and custodian of the liberties of the individual, uses an identification card. What we need in Australia to fight effectively all forms of abuse is just that-a proper identification of each Australian with a number, photograph and even a fingerprint. This will readily identify each of those who are on the employment register or the taxation records, or those who are social security recipients and receiving health and education subsidies or any form of government assistance. This common reference between all government agencies would curb all current abuses. If it is good enough for the USA it is certainly good enough for us in Australia when we are faced with the same problem. We are not in government to protect the guilty. We are not elected to encourage people to get greater handouts, to be more dependent on government and to make the innocent pay while the guilty are rewarded for corrupting the accepted forms of democratic governments.

The last 10 years has seen great changes in people's attitudes brought about by the generousness of governments seeking to retain power and the extravagant promises of Opposition seeking that power. This has led to the very costly illusion that all wants, not needs, will be satisfied by governments and that few care who take illegally from the public purse. Unchecked, the position can only worsen. Tax collections will deteriorate and our official unemployment figures will worsen. We have to take a stronger stand, not only on tax evasion but also on the total evasion and fraudulant problems that exist at the moment. Government policies over the last decade have given birth to the problem. The same governments should seek redress by the compulsory and ready identification of every Australian and every visitor through an identification card. We need a policeman to safeguard the public purse. A plastic policeman would be the most effective in preventing this form of abuse.

The Treasurer has referred to other problems in the Budget including cost pressures, rising unemployment, inflation, and lack of competitiveness which has build up protectionism-these are all related to the industrial situation. The Budget is very strong on the aspect that relief in personal income should be set against extravagant wage demands that have been going on in this country over the last few years. A recent visitor to the USA told me that the American unions lack political power and do not seek such power. Unionism is not compulsory and agreements when reached are observed. In all respects Australia is the very opposite of the fundamental precepts that make the US one of the most competitive, effective and free marketeers in the world. One might well ask: Where did this nation go wrong in its own approach to industrial matters? The same visitor said that workers in a business comparable to his own in the US were paid a basic $4 an hour for the first 40 hours of the week they worked. Only after that did overtime rates apply. There were few penalty rates.

I can imagine just how our own tourist, travel and accommodation industries in Australia would respond if offered the same conditions of employment as exist in the US. In that country annual leave is one week after the completion of two years continuous service and two weeks for each succeeding year. There is no 17 1/2 per cent loading, none of the four weeks annual leave that Australians get, none of the permanency given within Australia's Public Service or the permanency offered in private enterprise where the threat of strike retaliation is so often held at the employer's head. No buffer is offered to those out of work as is provided in Australia by an almost unlimited unemployment benefit with no real effective application of the means test. Even Blind Billy-perhaps I should refer to him as Mr Hayden-must see the result of this chaotic industrial position for Australia. Wage demands can lead only to higher costs, more protection, more unemployed and reducing markets internationally. Yet the Labor Opposition says that it will press for a shorter working week at the same pay. It will reintroduce wage indexation; it will suffer the increased number of unemployed people to maintain the gains of the past; it will introduce a $900m scheme to give the unemployed jobs, a re-run of the Regional Employment Development Scheme . Who will tell Opposition members that the games of the past were not productive games? They have left in their wake an entirely unbalanced economy, bankrupt and liquidated businesses and a growing number of unemployed. Industrial peace on the Australian Council of Trade Unions terms is bankruptcy for the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have a contractionary Budget brought down by a Liberal-National Country party coalition Government which is determined to pursue outdated monetarist policies which have become discredited all over the world. These policies are causing stagnation in our economy and resulting in untold hardship to the millions of Australians who are on low incomes or who are disadvantaged as a result of unemployment, sickness or disability. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) admitted that his economic policies have failed when, in his Budget Speech, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our overseas markets have shrunk. Economic growth has faltered. Unemployment is rising. Inflation remains far too high. Interest rates are hurting many of us.

What about all the promises this Government has made over the past seven years? Let me catalogue some of them. The Government said: 'We will expand our overseas trade; we will provide the conditions for economic growth; we will reduce unemployment; we will beat inflation; we will reduce interest rates'. I am not quoting from the speeches of Government Ministers because I do not need to do so . The people of Australia know that those promises were made and that they were broken. At last, however, the Treasurer has admitted the truth. Let me quote again from his Budget Speech. He said:
It is therefore unrealistic to expect a major recovery in the Australian economy to occur in the near future. There are no quick, easy solutions to our present problems.

Of course, the Treasurer has his two favourite scapegoats-the state of the world economy and what he calls the excessive growth of wages. The Australian people will not be fooled by such deception. Let me quote from a speech the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made to the forty-sixth ANZAAS congress in January 1975. He said:
National leaders look to parallels, they search for excuses when they should look simply to their own failures-failure to adapt, to perceive, to understand.
Here is another quote from the same speech. He said:

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature they would be saying 'we can overcome'.

There we have it. The Treasurer and the Government stand condemned by the words of their own leader, the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser. Now I turn to the other favourite scapegoat, excessive wage demands. According to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister the sole reason for inflation in this country is excessive wage demands. Apart from the fact that they concentrate on the large wage increases won by the more strongly and efficiently organised workers, such as the metal trades, and neglect the more modest increases won by other workers, wages alone do not contribute to inflation. Excessive interest rates, high profits and capital and speculative gains all contribute to inflation but the Government chooses to ignore those aspects because its capitalist friends in the big business world benefit from non-wage incomes. Unlike the person who works for wages, these financiers do not earn their incomes. Their wealth and their army of accountants and solicitors accumulate it for them.

Let us have no more of the nonsense that wage increases are the sole cause of inflation. Instead, I want to have a realistic look at the wages situation. An examination of the real wages share of the national income shows that there has been a drastic decline in the goods and services available to the wage earner. Real wages include not only the wages paid to wage and salary earners but also the value of the social wage, that is the value of the health, education, housing and welfare services provided by governments. From 1975-76 to 1981-82, the real wages share of the national income has dropped by a massive 8 per cent representing the cuts which the Federal Government has made in the funding provided for health, education, housing and welfare services. When wage and salary earners find that their income is eaten away by ever increasing taxes and that they must pay for services previously provided by government, of course they demand higher wages.

The Australian Labor Party will not permit this rip-off to continue. When we win government at the next Federal elections-they will be very soon-we will introduce a wages and incomes policy which will ensure a most equitable distribution of income, wealth and economic power. We will restore the social wage, but not overnight, because the rip-off of the past seven years cannot be redressed quickly without causing a severe dislocation to the economy. The Australian people are increasingly beginning to realise that, for a Labor government to operate effectively, it must have an uninterrupted period of at least two three-year terms with a Senate which is supportive of ALP policies. The 1973-75 Whitlam Labor Government did not hold real parliamentary power because of a hostile Senate. Three elections in three years frustrated its policies. Of course, it can be asked: Where are the funds coming from to include the areas of health, education, housing and welfare? We do not need to look very far when it is appreciated that the estimates are that over $15,000m has been lost in tax avoidance and evasion over the past seven years. Not only is this Government deceptive and dishonest; it is also protective of its crooked friends . The Government's attempts to slander the whole trade union movement by revealing thuggery in the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia has backfired on it because it has revealed something far worse. It has revealed that senior officials in the Public Service have connived and aided tax avoiders in the business world-let us call it by its correct name, the white collar crime world. These people are being shielded by Ministers and a government which believes that the only crime that the tax dodgers have committed is being found out.

The Treasurer huffs and puffs about tax avoidance in 1975 but at that time tax avoidance was but a shadow of the present massive pillage of some thousands of millions of dollars each year. This was one of the reasons why the Labor Government lost office in 1975. The financial world realised that, if the Labor Party remained in office, financiers would be unable to continue their robbery of the public purse. Members on the Government side cannot deny that it was the previous Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia who said that taxpayers had the right to arrange their financial affairs in such a manner as to minimise their tax liabilities. This was the top legal authority in the country in effect saying to potential tax dodgers: 'Go ahead with your tax avoidance. It is your right. We won't prosecute you.'

Make no mistake about it: The Treasurer is as guilty of encouraging the growth of this industry as is the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). They stood by and did nothing until their hands were forced by mounting public pressure and discontent and the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The estimate of $15,000m lost in tax avoidance and evasion could be conservative when it is appreciated that the Taxpayers Association has estimated that losses because of tax avoidance and evasion have reached a staggering $7,000m a year. This means that the average Australian household must pay an extra $35 a week to subsidise the tax dodgers. Little wonder that wage and salary earners are seeking substantial pay rises when the share of total personal income tax paid by them was 83 per cent last year compared with 76 per cent in 1975-76.

Having set a realistic background to the economic climate in which this Budget has been generated, I turn now to the Budget itself which under analysis indicates more deception and more dishonesty. Once again I quote from the Treasurer's Budget Speech in which he referred to the impact of the Budget on a family comprising a sole bread winner on $15,600 a year with a dependent spouse and two dependent children. The Treasurer said:
. . . the net weekly benefits for this family of this Budget would be about $16. 84 per week.

But, as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has pointed out, this is just not true. In the first place, the Budget provisions apply for only eight months of the 1982-83 financial year. Secondly, and even more importantly, the Treasurer completely ignores the fact that the Government has broken its promise that it would introduce tax indexation. The so-called tax cuts will be eaten away by the inflated taxes which the sole breadwinner will pay. The result of substituting honest figures for the dishonest figures used by the Treasurer is that the family will not be $16.84 a week better off but only $3.86 a week better off. What is more, if the family rents or already owns its own home it will not qualify for the home loan rebate and will be only 48c a week better off .

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is Horgan better off?

—That is right. How much better off is Horgan, as the honourable member for Hotham asks? So much for the credibility of a Treasurer who, even when he is explaining to taxpayers the effect of his Budget, attempts to deceive them. If that is what he is doing in relation to the Australian public, what on earth is he doing with the finances of this country?

SPEECH.PARA: I have already spoken in a grievance debate about the catastrophic effects of the economic policies of the Fraser Government on the young people in my electorate as a result of rapidly increasing unemployment and a lack of rental housing. The future for young school leavers is bleak indeed with total registered unemployment reaching 497,000 in July, including a 23 per cent increase during 1981-82 in long term unemployment. What is worse, nearly one- third of the unemployed has been out of work for more than six months. Appallingly, the Budget forecasts a continuation and an extension of the chronic unemployment situation and is an admission by the Treasurer of the complete irresponsibility of his Government in ignoring the calls of the Australian Labor Party for a manpower program embracing job creation schemes. The result of the Fraser Government's policies is that the living standards of Australians are rapidly dropping as witnessed by the fact that, although in 1955 there were only four countries with higher living standards than Australia, by 1979 there were 10 countries with higher living standards than Australia, including most of the west European countries.

In addition, the inequalities in the living standards between Australians on high incomes and those on low incomes have increased over the last seven years to the considerable disadvantage of the low income earners. This growing inequality has resulted from salary gains by high income earners, changes in the taxation system, interest rate increases and cuts in spending on government services. The taxation system has played an important role in financing government programs. That is why Opposition members have been concentrating on the gross irresponsibility of the Treasurer in not pursuing tax avoiders. As a result of changes between 1976 and 1981, the bottom 10 per cent of wage earners are paying 19 per cent more of their income in tax; the bottom 30 per cent are paying 4.5 per cent more; the top 20 per cent of wage earners are paying 0.7 per cent less; and the top one per cent is paying 9.4 per cent less. Taxes which hurt the rich, such as gift duty and probate tax, have been abolished. There is no justice or fairness in a taxation system where the tax burden falls most heavily on the poorest members of the community.

I turn now to health care which has reached a crisis situation in the eastern region of Melbourne. This is not surprising when the health section of Budget Paper No. 7 is analysed. Last year the States received $1,151m as identified in health grants. This year the total is to fall to $1,011m-a reduction of $140m or 12 per cent of last year's grants. But the figures in the Budget are based on an expected 11 per cent cost escalation for 1982-83 so that the reduction in real terms is 23 per cent. This reduction follows a reduction in real terms of 16 per cent in 1981-82 so that over the past two-year period there has been a total reduction of 39 per cent in identified health grants to the States. This is the last year when Commonwealth funds for hospitals and community health centres will be identified in the Budget. In future, the Commonwealth will make no provision for hospital and community health services. It will absorb health grants into the tax sharing grants. The allocation of the funds will then be entirely up to the States Government with no guarantee that those funds will be used for health care.

Last year, Victoria had to find $24m extra to maintain the health services provided by hospitals, community health and the school dental service. For this financial year, the position will be much worse. The identified health grant for Victoria will be $301m-a reduction of $20m instead of the additional $32m required to match inflation. The resultant shortfall represents an 18 per cent cut in Commonwealth funding which, together with State funding, means that the State Government has to provide another $93m more than last year just to keep the existing health services in operation. It must be borne in mind that the State Government is now paying 63 per cent of net operating costs as opposed to 56 per cent last year and 50 per cent for the previous years under the cost sharing agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. The striking contrast to the cuts in the public health sector is the generous treatment handed out to the private health sector. The Budget allocates an increase of $466m, representing 16 per cent above last year, for the private health sector with 83 per cent of these funds provided for medical practitioners, pharmacists and nursing homes. The private illness professions now receive 70 per cent of the total health budget.

The Budget demonstrates quite clearly the Fraser Government's commitment to the private sector in the field of health at the expense of the public sector. It is a continuation of the Government's policy of abandoning its responsiblities for the public hospitals of our country. Nowhere is this irresponsible policy more evident than in the public hospitals which service my electorate. The eastern suburbs association of hospitals has recently made a joint submission to local parliamentarians drawing attention to the crisis situation in hospital services in the eastern region of Melbourne. The rapid growth in population and the overall aging of the population have contributed to this crisis.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr MILTON

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, the rapid growth in population and the overall aging of the population contributed to the crisis, but the cuts in the public health funding by the Federal Government, which I outlined earlier in my speech, are the basic cause. The new State Labor Government is virtually powerless to overcome the health care crisis because it has resulted from the fact that total Commonwealth payments to the States have fallen by 8 per cent in real terms since 1975. The consequences of this irresponsible squeeze mean that the State Government can only rob Peter to pay Paul. However, any attempt to divert funds from other much needed areas of State responsibilities, such as education, welfare, housing and transport, would be grossly unfair and would not be acceptable to the Victorian people. We are therefore left with a health care crisis which the Federal Budget should have redressed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Medical services in the eastern region of Melbourne are at an appallingly low level. Cardiac, renal and investigational medicine services have to be provided in the central Melbourne area, involving long journeys by public and private transport for seriously ill patients. In the case of the Box Hill Hospital, 50 per cent of all admissions are emergencies and accidents, which means that the beds available for specialist elective medicine and surgery are very limited indeed. The general services funds which are available for the rehabilitation or maintenance of aged and handicapped people in the community are so meagre that it is a community at risk in health terms. In addition, hospital administrators have drawn attention on a number of occasions to the aging of the eastern region population, which means that unless a new geriatric centre is built in the area as a matter of urgency the health system for the aged will break down.

In the case of the William Angliss Hospital in Upper Ferntree Gully the temporary casualty section is totally inadequate. For example, it is quite common for 100 patients to be admitted in one day to the casualty section, which was designed to deal with fewer than 50 casualties a day. This hospital is the only public hospital in the Sherbrooke area, and it is vital that the Federal Government recognise that the hospital must be given special support, particularly because it is very difficult for frail and acutely ill patients to travel long distances, often by inadequate public transport, to the public hospitals of central Melbourne. Finally, I do not want to overlook the acute lack of nursing staff in the Knox region of my electorate which has been drawn to my attention by the Royal District Nursing Association. With the range and number of services provided by district nurses in the Knox region rapidly increasing, the staffing situation has remained static. It should be appreciated that home medical care is immeasurably cheaper than hospital care, yet both State and Federal Liberal governments have failed to provide support for this vital nursing service. With the Federal Government's user pays philosophy, there is no doubt that it will continue to ignore the appalling state of health in the eastern region of Melbourne. However, one thing is assured; that is, that the electors of the Federal seats of Casey, Deakin and Diamond Valley will not ignore the situation. All three Liberal held seats are vulnerable and the electors know that only a change to a Federal Australian Labor Party Government will assure them of a change to more positive and responsible health care policies.

I turn to the services provided in the Budget for disabled and handicapped people. For these people the 1982-83 Budget is a profound disappointment. The opportunity has been missed to provide funding for services which will give handicapped and disabled people the opportunity to become a part of the community where they live. Specifically, there is an urgent need for attendant care allowances for people with disabilities. The Government has announced that $100,000 will be provided for a pilot study for alternatives to attendant care being presently provided in institutions. Research has already indicated the need for those alternatives and a pilot scheme is not necessary. Direct payment should be made to disabled people to enable them to employ the attendant of their choice. Disabled people and their families in my electorate are calling to the Government to provide an attendant care scheme as a matter of urgency.

The program of aids to disabled people has been increased from $2.4m for 1981- 82 to $3.6m for 1982-83. The funding is grossly inadequate and should be increased to $10m to have any appreciable impact on the number of disabled people requiring aids and renovations to their home. Unfortunately, I have not time in this debate to deal with the inadequate provisions in this Budget for aged income security, children's services, education and housing. I hope to deal with these matters in later debates in this House. In my view it is important to expose the dishonesty and deceptiveness of the Treasurer in both the presentation and the framing of the 1982-83 Budget. It is important for Australians to realise that the Liberal-National Country Party Government is quite unscrupulous in its determination to protect the wealthy and the powerful. The recent debates in this House on ministerial responsibility show quite clearly how facts can be distorted and tax avoiders and evaders protected when the Government perceives that its financial supporters are under attack.

This Budget was framed for an early November election but the publication of the reports of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry with the revelations of Government neglect in failing to prevent white collar crime, bribery and corruption has torpedoed the Government's chances of winning an election. While the Budget appears to provide some benefits to low income families, it has been shown quite clearly how inflation and the continuing neglect of the health and welfare of Australian families will eat away the benefits. For seven years the Liberal-National Country Party Government has rifled the pockets of the people and now, by producing some tax concessions out of the hat, it thinks it can fool voters once again. We need a comprehensive program of policies which will generate economic activity and lead Australia back to prosperity but only the Labor Party has the will and the ability to produce a creative and well planned Budget which could achieve those aims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House tonight to a report I have received from one of my constituents of a visit from a person who identified himself as an immigration officer and whose mission was to crack down on illegal workers. The scene was a bike shop in Fyshwick, which is an industrial suburb in my electorate. It was last Wednesday. A man walked into the shop, stated that he was from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and said: 'I guess you blokes know why I am around'. He stated that he was looking for noggies. Noggies, I understand, is a derogatory term for Asians. He then asked how many workers were employed there and what nationality they were. When assured that all the workers were Australians he left, but not before stating that he was also looking for Dapto dogs and offered a warning for anyone who fitted that description.

SPEECH.PARA: I was appalled by this account. There is very little sympathy in this community for illegal workers, it is true, but no one can condone the attitude or behaviour of that immigration officer. Our ethnic communities are an important and valuable part of our Australian community and no immigrant-indeed, no individual-deserves that derogatory name calling. The fact that it allegedly comes from an official from the Department casts serious doubts over the Government's guidelines for the crackdown on illegal immigrants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my view, the administrative process is not working properly. Certainly it is not working the way the vast majority of Australian people want it to. It seems to me that government administration is breaking down because of the rigid discipline of the party system and the fierce ambition for power by political leaders. That means that political expediency and point scoring override all other considerations. No thought is given to the effect on public administration. Leaders will use every opportunity to score a point or ' tip a bucket' on their opponents. Perhaps that satisfies their egos. Perhaps they think it wins them public favour or support from their followers. One thing is certain. While politicians concentrate their attention on political expediency and point scoring the administration of government will get worse.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that above all else the Australian people expect their governments to be good, effective and efficient administrators and also that the affairs of government will be conducted honestly and with high integrity and principles. It is about time politicians in this country started to respond to what the people want rather than what they themselves try to impose on the people. Naturally, while this point scoring battle is taking place the process of public administration is left to public servants. Knowing that their jobs are protected by permanency the public servants are not concerned about efficiency or giving service to the public but are much more concerned with promotion up the ladder. The constant losers are the Australian people.

Revelations by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Williams Royal Commission, inquiries into the Health Department, the Australian Dairy Corporation and the meat substitution scandal, all show clear evidence of how government administration is breaking down and the effect it is having on the country. The Australian people want politicians to co-operate more on a bipartisan basis so as to improve our public administration. If a good idea is put forward by the Opposition it should be looked at objectively. Equally if there is a problem with administration all parties should be more concerned to make improvements rather than simply score political points.

The fact that our present system is not working properly is self-evident. The system needs to be improved so that we can go forward into the twenty-first century with confidence. Our present system has a long history of tradition and hard-won experience. The good features should be retained while improving the administrative processes to take account of the modern computer age. The Parliament is made up of two Houses and both Houses have a vital role to play in both legislation and administration. Essentially, governments are made in the House of Representatives while the Senate is a House of review. That is good. Let us keep those basic features. But we can still make improvements. Both the House of Representatives and the Senate are dominated by party allegiances, so that the attitudes adopted in the Lower House will be duplicated in the Upper House. That is not good. If governments are made in the House of Representatives that House should be entirely responsible for forming the government and establishing government policy. That means that all Ministers should come from the House and no Ministers from the Senate. The Senate should be responsible to review government legislation and to keep a close eye on how efficiently and effectively those policies are working.

Let me now look more closely at the re-structuring of both Houses. Assume firstly that all Ministers are members of the House of Representatives. We must also keep in mind the expectations that the public have for their elected members and elected governments and the demands of modern administration. The public expect that their elected member will have some impact on public administration, regardless of the member's party affiliation. The Opposition of the day must be given a more constructive role in the administrative processes. If that is not done and the governmnent of the day treats the Opposition as a bunch of fools, approximately 45 per cent of the people of Australia will always be disenfranchised.

The other factor that must be considered is that one man as Minister cannot possibly oversee all that is happening in his Department. I suggest therefore that the party that wins the most seats in the House of Representatives have the right to form a government and appoint Ministers. There should also be a series of committees formed that parallel the ministerial portfolios. Membership of the committees should be drawn from all parties with the Government having the majority. The committee chairman should also act as an assistant to the Minister . The role of the committees should be to assist the Minister and the Government in the development of policies and legislation. The committees could also visit the far flung areas of the country to see situations first hand, accept submissions and talk to a wide range of people with an interest in a problem. The committee should work in conjunction with the Minister, not independent of him. When Cabinet is required to make a decision--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to report to the House the breaking of 21-year drought of football premierships by the Swan Districts Football Club. Last Saturday with a fierce determination and strong team play which has become the hallmark of the Swans' game they dispatched Claremont by a margin of 18.19 (127) to 11.12 (78) after leading all the way. As a result the team's 20 players brought joy and satisfaction to their many loyal supporters in my electorate. No coach could want a better combination than Keith Narkle, Phil Narkle, Graham Melrose, Don Langsford, Peter Kenny, Ron Boucher, Allan Sidebottom, Alan Cransberg, Murray Rance, Ross Fitzgerald, Tom Mullooly, Jeff Davidson, Bill Skwirowski, Stan Nowotny, Jon Fogarty, Tony Solin, Leon Baker, Don Holmes, Michael Richardson and Bradley Shine.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, on a day of team triumph there are always great individual efforts as well. Graham Melrose, captain and veteran of more than 320 league games, capped a year of great leadership by winning the Simpson Medal for best player on the ground. John Todd, coach, experienced years of hard work and disappointment as he moulded a talented team into tough final round contestants. The victory on Saturday is thus yet another mighty achievement for one of the great of Western Australian football. This year he has been a master of team psychology off the field as well as on, creating a genuine club solidarity at Bassendean. On Saturday Swans' vice-captain, Phil Narkle, played his hundredth league game in the form which made him this year's Sandover medallist. From all players there were acts of individual courage too numerous to cite in detail. One merits particular attention. Ruckman Ron Boucher played on a badly strained ankle, turned during the previous evening's training. He played in pain despite massive pain killing injections disabling enough in themselves.

Perhaps no person deserves more praise than retiring Swans President John Cooper. John Cooper completes this year seven years of service in that position. In that time he has dragged together a club too used to defeat despite the great strengths of its membership and players. He was a key figure in the appointment of John Todd as coach. He brought to the presidency the vast experience of a player, colts coach, club secretary, treasurer and vice-president. His retirement from the presidency-a retirement he enters as a life member of the club-is regretted by the many who wish him well in it. The House may be assured that even though Saturday's result is the pinnacle of Swan's achievement over the last 21 years it will be only one peak in a mountain range of victories over the next decade and beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise a very serious problem that has been brought to me by a constituent. It involves a lady whose daughter sought, but failed to gain, admission to a faculty of medicine at a university in New South Wales. The young lady subsequently went overseas to obtain admission to a university in Europe, where she entered the third year of a medicine course. She became pregnant. The mother approached me, trying to get this young woman a supporting mother's benefit. She was an Australian citizen, she was pregnant and she developed a heart condition which meant that she could not return to Australia. In addition the cost of the air fare was $1,800 or more. I was naturally extremely sympathetic for the plight of this young girl. I approached the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and was appalled to find no assistance at all was available to this young woman. She was a young Australian abandoned in Europe with a pregnancy and with a heart condition. Although age pensions are portable-all sorts of other pensions can be paid in Europe-this Australian citizen was totally alone, totally deserted and totally isolated.

SPEECH.PARA: I am raising this matter tonight because I really believe that if this Minister had any sympathy at all for Australians in difficulty overseas he would do whatever he possibly could to pay some sort of special benefit to an Australian in the circumstances that I have outlined to the House tonight. The Minister instead sent me a pamphlet which I was to send to this young lady with a covering letter explaining to her why she could not get any assistance and why she just had to fend for herself in Europe. If ever there was an incentive for a young woman to undertake the appalling crime of an abortion, it is this situation. We have a Government which has instituted many debates in this House on the issue of abortion, which funds abortions throughout the nation but which will give no aid whatsoever to Australian women, young girls, who happen to fall pregnant overseas. It is the inexperienced women who fall pregnant. These are people in very difficult circumstances. Instead of the sympathy and support of this Government going out to help young women overseas, it does nothing. It refuses to help.

One third of the constituents in my electorate were born overseas. Many Australians, many young people, travel. They go overseas for work experience, to visit families and to stay with relations. In this case this young woman has become pregnant and has obtained no help at all from this Government. Her mother has had to go to Europe at great expense to care for her and to be with her. Anyone in this country should be entitled to some form of payment when he or she is distressed, when he or she has no support at all. Here we have a government which talks about being fair and charitable and thinking of the underdog. It is a hollow sham when it comes to Australian girls who are overseas, who are in difficulty and who need help. I hope that this appalling situation obtains some publicity in the various journals in this country so that people can note that this Government, which talks a great deal about assisting Australians in difficulty, would do nothing at all to assist this young woman from my constituency who had to leave her university course and was abandoned in Europe without any assistance, without any finances. She had gone to Europe to try to obtain her medical degree and now she is a woman in great difficulty. I have been very distressed by the circumstances of this matter and I raise it tonight so that honourable members can note with concern the hypocrisy of this so-called Liberal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) just came into the House. After lengthy discussion with his solicitor it was decided not to proceed with the case. I shall read the letter without mentioning names. It states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: However the difficulty in suing either of these people-
The people who owned the horse-

is the fact that they have been given virtual immunity by the rule in the High Court case of SGIO v. Trigwell (1979) 26 Australian Law Reports 67. In that case a majority of the High Court decided that the owner or occupier of a property adjoining the highway is under no legal obligation to users of it so to keep and maintain his hedges, fences and gates as to prevent animals from straying onto it, and that he is not under any duty as between himself and users of it to take reasonable care to prevent any of his animals, not known to be dangerous, from straying onto it. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government accept the list of nine areas of Commonwealth responsibility for civil defence outlined in the note concluded on the subject following the Commonwealth-State Ministerial Meeting of 21 June 1966.
(2) If not, which ones does it reject.
(3) How has it implemented those responsibilities it has accepted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The statement of Commonwealth and State responsibilities, endorsed by the Commonwealth Government in 1967, was a codification of the broad division of responsibilities that had stood essentially unchanged since the 1950s; the arrangements were, for example, referred to in the Minister for the Interior's statement on 29 September 1959 in the House of Representatives. The broad division of responsibilities remains applicable given the recognition that State and Commonwealth counter-disaster capabilities provide the practical basis for civil defence in present and foreseeable strategic circumstances. That recognition was implicit in the establishment of the Natural Disasters Organisation in 1974 and explicit in the 1976 Defence White Paper. For the information of honourable members, the Commonwealth's responsibilities are provided in the answer to Part 3 and the State responsibilities are as follows.
1. Establishing and operating a State Civil Defence Organisation including Voluntary Civil Defence Services.
2. Co-ordination of State and Local Government Services and other services in Civil Defence activities.
3. Civil Defence planning and preparations in conjunction with the Commonwealth and other States.
4. Preparation of legislation required for Civil Defence purposes within areas of State jurisdiction.
5. The publication and dissemination of information, advice and instructions on Civil Defence.
6. Supply to the Commonwealth of scientific and technical information on Civil Defence matters resulting from investigations by State Departments or Authorities.
7. Liaison and co-operation with neighbouring States or Commonwealth Territories on all Civil Defence matters of common interest.
(3) Commonwealth responsibilities and their implementation are:
1. 'Provide the States with information on the strategic situation and on possible forms and scales of attack, and give national guidance on Civil Defence policy'.

Implementation: Major statements in recent years where the Government and the Department of Defence have given assessments of Australia's strategic situation and, in the absence of identifiable threat, provided the basis for civil defence policy are, the 1972 Australian Defence Review, the 1976 Defence White Paper, the Minister for Defence's statements in a budgetary context on 22 September 1977, 24 October 1978, and on 29 March 1979, the Prime Minister's statement of 19 February 1980 relating to Afghanistan, the Minister for Defence's statements on 25 March 1980, 26 August 1980, 5 May 1981 and 29 April 1982-the last in particular providing a global assessment. The Department has also provided, through its annual Defence Reports and through its series of capital city seminars in 1980 and 1981, substantial detail on strategic assessments and basis for planning.

Implementation: The Australian Capital Territory has its own Emergency Service. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment is responsible for civil defence in Australia's island territories and in consultation with NDO has developed counter-disaster plans.

3. 'Arrange such co-operation between Commonwealth and States as is necessary to ensure the effectiveness of Civil Defence planning and preparations and provide assistance in the implementation thereof as agreed with the States'.

Implementation: The Commonwealth arranges regular meetings with and between the State Emergency Services. It organises conferences, training and national disaster plans involving the wide range of organisations that would be concerned in an emergency. It provides financial assistance for equipment and a number of other support programs. Information on these matters appears annually in the Defence Report.
4. 'Provide advanced training facilities for selected students in consultation with the States'.
Implementation: The Charter of the Australian Counter-Disaster College states:

'The role of the Australian Counter Disaster College is to contribute to the development of an efficient Australian counter-disaster capacity by training selected personnel in counter-disaster and civil defence requirements, by fostering understanding and co-operation between appropriate elements of the community, and by undertaking research into selected aspects of disaster'.

In meeting its aim of training those who will train others, the College conducts courses on counter-disaster planning, management, and team leadership. Special seminars held in recent years have addressed, inter alia, the problems of dealing with mass burns, port disasters, and exotic animal diseases.
5. 'Provide, in consultation with the States, manuals and other documents for Civil Defence Training and the information of the public'.
Implementation: Counter-Disaster manuals and pamphlets made available over the years and progressively being updated, are:
Radiation fallout on plants and animals.
Protective measures against radiation from fallout.
6. 'Supply to the States scientific and technical information on Civil Defence matters'.
Implementation: The Natural Disasters Organisation provides:
a central library service for books and film managed by the Australian Counter Disaster College;
through the College, distribution of information received from Emergency Management and Civil Defence authorities overseas;
assistance through a fallout shelter survey which has identified some 3 million shelter spaces in capital cities.
7. 'Arrange for co-operation by Commonwealth Departments and Authorities and the Armed Forces with State Civil Defence organisations'.

Implementation: There are no specifically and solely State Civil Defence organisations. There are State Counter Disaster and Emergency Service organisations with the function of countering natural disasters and providing a basis for civil defence, as was recognised in the Minister for Defence's statement on 27 June 1974, and in the 1976 Defence White Paper. The Natural Disasters Organisation acts as the national co-ordination agency in providing Commonwealth physical assistance including Defence Force resources to these organisations in dealing with major disasters. The Defence Force also regularly provides physical assistance to these organisations in dealing with emergency life saving situations such as search and rescue, aero medical evacuation and the supply of stores and equipment. The Defence Force assists with training support to State organisations including the provision of helicopters for familiarisation, rescue winching and personnel transport on exercises.
8. 'Arrange for Interstate and Commonwealth assistance as necessary in an emergency'.

Implementation: Commonwealth arrangements to assist the States in emergencies have been demonstrated frequently, for example, in the 1974 Brisbane floods, in Cyclone Tracy, and in the 1976 and 1982 Tasmanian bush-fires. Plans exist for dealing with the effect of cyclones, and the impact of events such as earthquakes that may occur without warning. A national plan to deal with an outbreak of exotic animal disease has been prepared in conjunction with the Bureau of Animal Health. The National Emergency Operations Centre has been established to co-ordinate national efforts in a disaster.
9. 'Prepare Commonwealth Civil Defence legislation as may be required'.
Implementation: State powers exist, and in some cases legislation. Commonwealth legislation is not presently seen as necessary, nor, even were a threat to occur , would any necessarily be required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken to implement the civil defence aspects of the responsibilities of the Natural Disasters Organisation.
(2) What priority has been assigned to different levels of threat to Australia' s civil defence.
(3) What steps have been taken to ensure the adoption of appropriate measures to protect local communities against the consequence of harassment by small opposing forces.
(4) What steps have been taken to protect Australian population centres by either (a) evacuation or (b) sheltering in the event of nuclear attack.

(5) What particular steps have been taken to protect by either (a) evacuation or (b) sheltering affected populations in the event of nuclear attack on (i) Pine Gap, Northern Territory, (ii) Northwest Cape, Western Australia, (iii) Darwin Royal Australian Air Force Base and (iv) Cockburn Sound, Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Natural Disasters Organisation's responsibility for civil defence is to support the development of a core civil defence structure in the various States and Territories by guidance and support of State/Territory Emergency Service organisations. Civil defence capabilities and planning appropriate to Australia' s strategic circumstances are being developed in close liaison with State/ Territory authorities responsible for counter disaster and civil defence planning and operations. NDO provides a range of physical and financial support programs to States/Territories to assist with the development of their respective counter disaster and core civil defence capabilities. NDO has provided State/Territory authorities with technical information to assist them in the identification of suitable public fallout shelter accommodation in major population centres. The Organisation also provides public information material on nuclear protection appropriate to the Australian situation, through the State /Territory Emergency Services.

(2) The Government's assessment, which has been provided to the public over the past decade is that there is a very low likelihood of any hostilities on Australian territory and that nuclear war, and hence nuclear attack upon Australia, is also unlikely. If nuclear war between the superpowers were to occur it could not be discounted that Australia, along with a lot of other countries might become a target. Government policy thus continues to be directed towards helping to ensure that global war is deterred. The contingencies that are emphasised in defence planning are those involving low level harassment and small scale raids. While these are not considered likely to occur they are less improbable than a major assault without prior warning.

(3) to (5) I refer the honourable member to my answer to Question No. 4686, in which I provided details on the broad responsibilities for civil defence accepted over the past 20 years by State and Commonwealth Governments. In view of the Commonwealth's assessment that the threat of any attack against Australia is low, the judgement on whether resources should be committed now to the steps referred to in the honourable member's question would properly lie within the responsibilities of the relevant State or Territory Government.
